title: one must insulate britain queen
story: One must insulate Britain! Is the Queen a secret radical Leftie Her Majestys long reign has probably produced more carbon dioxide than any of her subjects, says Fleet Street Fox. But shes turning into a bit of a hippy in her old ageopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsIn general, any -year-old dripping in jewellery that costs more than the average house will, when discussing climate change, state that it is someone aposs problem. And so it was when the Queen attended the opening of the Welsh Senedd, wearing pearl earrings the size of a mint humbug, shortly before stepping into a Kevlar-plated limousine to drive a single, solitary mile to the station where her personal train awaited her.She was caught on a livestream discussing the upcoming COP climate change summit, saying: Extraordinary isnapost it... still donapost know whoaposs coming, no idea... we only know about people who are not coming and itaposs really irritating when they talk, but donapost do.She might have meant it was irritating when guests donapost reply to invitations, but most people have taken it as a broad criticism of world leaders failing to save the planet.   Seeing as this is a woman whose homes contain a large amount of the planet that was mined, carved, shot, skinned, robbed or stolen before it was squirrelled away for her and her family, you might reasonably conclude itaposs a bit rich for her to criticise. But she has done rather more than most of her Prime Ministers to de-carbonise the country. Buckingham Palace has heat and hot water produced by a combined heat and power plant, with solar  in the offing. Windsor Castle boasts hydroelectric power fed by the River Thames, while Balmoral produces  tonnes of compost every year from its organic waste. She also sends old staff computers to be recycled, and redistributed by charities in the developing world.A quarter of the UKaposs power comes from wind turbines, a vast number of which are on offshore farms she technically owns, and which are leased from the Crown Estate. Sheaposs patron of  environmental charities, her husband had more than , and their eldest son has a -year-old car which has an engine converted to run on wine and cheese.Aside from the fact thataposs the automobile version of Boris Johnson, itaposs more than anyoneaposs done to make  Downing Street any greener. In fact, the real-time website displaying the PMaposs energy use is currently kaput. On the same day she was caught making a snfy remark about the Chinese refusal to come to the environmental party, climate activist Greta Thunberg said COP would involve many pledges that -you look into the details - are more or less meaningless but they just say them in order to have something to say, in order for media to have something to report about.And so there are two uncomfortable things to consider. The first is that,the Chinese donapost turn up, there is no chance the rest of the world could limit global warming to an extra . degrees. Islands will be lost to melted ice caps, species will go extinct, and mass immigrations will take place, all because Xi Jinping is too much of a capitalist.The second is that Her Majesty might be a secret hippy. An unco-operative crusty. A friend of Swampy. A hippy-dippy, namby-pamby, ooh-itaposs-all-got-to-be-a-bit-green, woke old greenhouse whinger.Read more The evidence for: . Sells own chutney outside house . Always carrying a bunch of flowers . Finds money unnecessary And against: OH COME ON.The woman has  gas-guzzling limousines,  private homes, another  she uses for work, two jets, three helicopters, a train, and had to have her diesel-powered yacht prised out of her hands. In , it was calculated she had travelled more than a million miles, equivalent to going around the world  times, in the course of her reign. And thataposs before you calculate the cost to the planet of  children,  grandchildren, and  great-grandchildren, not one of whom is ever going to catch the bus.Throw in the fact sheaposs a widow living in single-glazed, drafty palaces, with hundreds of bedrooms, and thousands of staff, all consuming water and electricity just because she canapost find her own cornflakes in the morning, and Queen Elizabeth II has a bigger carbon footprint than a T-Rex in a coal mine. Itaposs no good saying but she goes around switching the lights off. Thereaposd be a lot more light to go round,she hadnapost bothered to give us Prince Andrew.  But you canapost be a totally green Queen, whatever Meghan Markle might think. A Royal simply isnapost royal any morethey ditch the palaces, staff, and multiple forms of transport. Brenda from down the road might be able to hop on the bus to get to Sainsburyaposs, but Brenda from SWA is going to struggle with it. The Royal travel, state visits, and constant wardrobe changes are part of a job no-one wants to say is surplus to requirements. Staff, security, consumption, and the problems of maintaining ,-year-old castles are something she cannot do much about.Itaposs not like sheaposs about to live in a tunnel under Finsbury Square, or block the M in rush hour while daring a lorry driver to drag her onto the hard shoulder, and shouting SOD THE AMBULANCES!But one of the benefits of a Queen is being able to get her to say or do things that are accidentally overheard but entirely intended, like when David Cameron asked her to intervene in the Scottish independence referendum, or a politician not a million miles from Michael Gove lied that she was pro-Leave, and next chance she got the Queen dressed up as the EU flag to put him back in his box.  Thataposs why it was her name on the COP invitations. Itaposs why her being irritated will be reported worldwide. Itaposs why, perhaps, shamefaced world leaders will suddenly respond to a summit invitation they had hitherto ignored. Queens have power, and old ladies can tickle even the least-guilty conscience with just the tiniest hint of disapproval. Anyone who thinks they havenapost been naughty will start to wonderin fact they have. Those who think the world has forgotten what they did, will be reminded the world should remember what theyaposll do next. The most ardent republican feels the knee creak into a curtsey, when this particular woman asks how far youaposve come. Whether her words were planned or accidental, they will do more than all the Prime Ministeraposs windbaggery to actually move world leaders closer to common sense. That she can do that is the reason we let her get away with everything .Hopefully at the summit sheaposll get the chance to say well, one SHOULD insulate Britain, shouldnapost one  Seeing as she loathed Margaret Thatcher, married a refugee and is literally the head of a union, sheaposs probably more of a radical Leftie than anyone will ever realise.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Xi JinpingThe QueenBoris JohnsonBuckingham PalaceCrown EstateEnergyRoyal FamilyClimate changeJewelleryPoliticsSolar power" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: 6 times royals were caught
story: times royals were caught saying controversial things - mic mix-up and cruel insultsAfter The Queens frustrated comments about world leaders and their blasé attitudes to COP were unearthed yesterday, we take a look at some of the funnier slip ups other members of The Royal Family have made over the yearsThe royals have been caught out several times over the years Image: GettyByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Oct | comments The Queen has ruffled feathers after voicing her irritation at world leaders for not taking climate change seriously enough.Ahead of the COP summit in Glasgow next month, Her Majesty was caught having a pop at the Chinese and Russian leaders, who wonapost commit to attending. The -year-old monarch described the situation as irritating when talking about the leadersapos seemingly laissez-faire attitude to the summit. Speaking after the opening of the Welsh parliamentaposs sixth session, she said: Extraordinary isn’t it. I’ve been hearing all about COP, [we] still don’t know who is coming, no idea.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here We only know about people who are not coming and it’s really irritating when they talk, but they donapost do. The royals normally stay clear of political opinions, but many people have praised Her Majesty for expressing her frustration. Her comment is far from the first time a member of The Firm has been caught making a comment that has raised eyebrows. Charlesaposs jibe at BBC reporter While on holiday in the Swiss Alps with sons William and Harry in , Prince Charles accidentally let slip his true feelings for BBC royal reporter, Nicholas Witchell. Surrounded by reporters asking questions about Charlesaposs upcoming wedding to Camilla Parker Bowles, Charles appeared to lose his patience. After the reporter asked him how he felt about his nuptials, Charles said: Iaposm very glad you heard of it anyway. Then, under his breath and with a grimace, he said: Bloody people. I canapost bear that man. Heaposs so awful. He really is. Although said in a quieter tone, itaposs impossible to knowCharles intended for his comment to be heard - he did have dozens of microphones on him, after all. Row with Russia On a trip to Canada in , Prince Charles ruffled feathers once more when he compared Russian president Vladimir Putin to Adolf Hitler. The comment came about while he chatted to a -year-old Jewish woman who had fled from Poland during World War Two The Daily Mail reported the heir to the throne said: “Putin is doing just about the same as Hitler.” The alleged comments sparked a furious response from Moscow, with a spokesman for the Russian Foreign Ministry accusing him and the British press of a smear campaign. story: Cornish Loch Ness Monster spotted off coast - and locals think there are moreSightings of Cornwalls Loch Ness Monster - a legendary creature called Morgawr - have been on the rise with locals saying the coast is being stalked by a huge surviving species of plesiosaurSightings of Cornwalls Loch Ness Monster are on the riseImage: Getty ImagesByEd CullinaneLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Sightings of Cornwallaposs has a apos Loch Ness Monster apos have been on the rise as locals claim the coast is being stalked by a huge surviving species of plesiosaur.Sightings of the mystical creature in waters off the Duchy have been on the increase adding to belief of the existence of a long-necked legendary creature called aposMorgawrapos - Cornish for sea giant. Despite one leading scientist casting doubt on the existing evidence - with only grainy photographs in existence - many locals remain convinced it is real. It has been described at ious points as like a large snake, a hideous hump-backed creature a long-necked sea monster and an elephant waving its trunk.Have you got pictures of Morgawr, Nessie or another mysterious beastie  Get in touch at webnews@mirrorAnd with the number of dferent descriptions, some have now even suggested there might even be more than one strange creature stalking the Cornish waters.Cornish local Joan Hawthorne wrote: It seems crazy to many I know, but there has been so many sightings that how can they rule out for sure whether it exists  Scotland has cashed in for years on the Loch Ness monster - maybe we should start doing the same in Cornwall. Other suggested the sightings may have even been the Loch Ness Monster visiting Cornwall on holiday - or joked he could have a second home here. Sarah Barnes wrote: Thataposs why I didnapost see Nessie while in Scotland. Sheaposs on her Hollibobs down in Cornwall. Timon Hewlett added: Bet Nessie has a second home down here somewhere. Residents and visitors have recorded many sightings of aposMorgawrapos over the years since the first long-necked beast was allegedly caught by a fisherman  years ago.  This included the most credible yet by a former employee of the Natural History Museum, who claimed to capture the reptile on camera around  years ago. John Holmes, who worked as a higher scientic officer at the Natural History Museum, released strange footage which he had filmed three years prior in Gerrans Bay, off the Roseland Peninsula. He said at the time: My pet theory is that it was a living fossil. I think that there is a group of plesiosaurs going around in the oceans of the world. All around Britain there have been sightings of sea serpents.Despite the claims, a palaeontologist at Nottingham Natural History Adam S. Smith, said they almost certainly didnapost exist.He added: Unfortunately, living- plesiosaurs almost certainly do not exist today.In an extensive article on his website aposPlesiosauriaapos, he wrote: Even a good photograph of a clearly plesiosaur-like organism would not provide conclusive proof for the existence of living plesiosaurs. It is too easy to hoax photographs, increasingly so with the advent of Photoshop, etc. A compelling photograph, or preferably a good series of photographs taken in quick succession, would certainly warrant further investigation. story: Entire street of eight cottages for sale at £, costs same as one-bed London flatThe street, close to Chorley Old Road in Bolton, Lancashire, has a terrace of  cottages on the market at the same price as a one-bedroom apartment in central LondonThe street where  cottages cost the same as a one-bed London flat Image: Mercury Press  MediaByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Oct | commentsA street has eight cottages up for sale that cost £, which is the same as a one-bedroom flat in London. The terrace of eight cottages is former mill cottages that were built to house workers in Bolton, Lancashire.The guide price for each property ranges from £, - £, and some have back gardens.Yet a modest one-bedroom apartment in London is the same price as this entire row of cottages. Whilst the cottages may need a spruce up, they are in a habitable condition apart from one which needs a total refurbishment. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletterEdward Feather, the associate director at Pugh Auctions said: Six of the cottages have two bedrooms and two of them have one bedroom.Seven of the cottages are habitable but all of them need updating and one of themneeds total refurbishment.The bargain houses up for grabs are perfect for investors or first-time buyers who want to start from scratch.The decor of each house is minimalist so savvy home buyers can create their dream home from the get-go. The properties were originally for former Mill Cottages that were built to house workers at Nelson Mill, part of Boltonaposs rich industrial heritage. He adds: The row of cottages is close to Chorley Old Road which is a busy residential area with shops and lots of facilities.  Gaskell Community Primary School is rated Good by Ofsted is directly opposite the cottages. Thomasson Park is nearby and the centre of Bolton is only a mile away. Each property is up for auction for dramatically less than a place in London meaning the buyer will have spare cash to splurge on the renovation. The online auction opens for bids next Tuesday  October and closes the following day. And it certainly isnapost one to miss out on! Edward adds: While the eight cottages are being offered inidually, itaposs a condition of sale that all eight properties need to meet their inidual reserves for a sale of any of the properties to take place.If any of the eight properties do not meet their reserve then none of the properties will be sold, regardless of whether their reserves have been met or not.The reserve prices range from £, to £, and the total guide price for all eight properties is £,. news uk-news fergies-rocky-relationship-royals-livid-"Sarah Ferguson says royal family moves together as a unitByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Oct | comments She joined the royal family when she married Prince Andrew in a huge ceremony at Westminster Abbey in , and since that day, Sarah Ferguson, who celebrates her nd birthday today, has certainly had a rocky relationship with her royal relatives.Not only has she endured the breakdown of her marriage and subsequent orce but she also found herself snubbed from royal events.However, in recent years, it seems Fergie has been welcomed back into the royal fold and even stayed with the Queen at Balmoral this summer.Here, we look back at her bumpy relationship with the royals... Early years Prince Andrew and Sarah had been friends since they were children but it wasnapost until  that they started dating after being seated together at Royal Ascot that year.They got engaged nine months later on February ,  - his th birthday - and Andrew gave his we-to-be a ruby engagement ring. Their wedding was a grand affair at Westminster Abbey and they shared a kiss on the balcony of Buckingham Palace like Prince Charles and Princess Diana before them. In the early days of their romance, Fergie bonded with the Queen over their shared love of horses, according to Vanity Fair.It was also reported that she won over Prince Philip with her sharp sense of humour and the interest she showed in her father-in-lawaposs favourite sport of carriage driving.Split from Andrew Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.After their wedding, the couple welcomed two daughters - Princess Beatrice in  and Princess Eugenie in .But cracks had begun to appear in their relationship as Andrewaposs naval career saw him away from the family for long periods of time. And in  they split with their orce finalised in . Speaking to US TV host Ernie Manouse in , Sarah spoke about palace courtiers, who she said made her le dficult. She explained: “My deal was that I was marrying my man, who happened to be a prince and a naval officer. “But what I got was not the man, I got the palace and didn’t get him... and the courtiers told me I had to go to Buckingham Palace and he had to go to sea. “For our marriage, I saw him  days a year.” Livid royals  Despite splitting from Andrew, Fergie was still invited to join the family for their traditional summer holiday in Balmoral in . However, the politeness disappeared on one excruciatingly embarrassing moment when intimate photos of her appeared on the front pages. She had been snapped having her toes sucked by her financial advisor, Texan millionaire John Bryan. Other photos in the set also showed the couple kissing, embracing and frolicking in the pool and they appeared in newspapers.And while at Balmoral, Fergie had to walk into breakfast that morning while the family all looked at the pictures. Speaking on Channel aposs documentary, Fergie Vs Diana: Royal Wives at War, royal expert Jennie Bond said: There she was, with all the members of the royal family, who traditionally have all the papers laid out on the breakfast table. The scene when she went into the dining room was horrendous because there were her brothers-in-law turning over the pages and staring at her naked top half of her body. It was excruciatingly embarrassing and she went to the Queen, and the Queen was livid. She was absolutely furious with Sarah. Prince Philip rt  One royal who was said to be especially furious with the toe sucking pictures was the late Prince Philip.His biographer Gyles Brandreth once said Philip thought Sarah was simply beyond the pale and gave her a wide berthBrandreth claimed the Duke of Edinburgh decided that aposenough was enoughapos and that he didnapost want anything more to do with her.He told MailOnline : When I asked him [Prince Philip] why he wouldn’t see Sarah, he said: ‘I am not vindictive.’Then, looking at me directly, he added emphatically: ‘I am not vindictive, but I don’t see the point.’ The pair are said to have not met for  years, with Fergie banished from ­Balmoral each summer before Philip arrived. Diana feud It wasnapost just Prince Philip that Sarah stopped talking to - she also had a falling out with her friend Princess Diana.In the early years of their marriages, Diana and Fergie had a close bond. They were often pictured chatting at events, such as Ascot, and took their children on skiing holidays together with Fergie frequently describing Diana as her best friend. But itaposs thought that in  the pairaposs relationship became strained and at the time of Dianaaposs tragic death a year later, they were not on speaking terms.According to the Daily Mail, the reason stemmed back to Sarahaposs autobiography, My Story, released in .Before it was published, Diana is reported to have told her former sister-in-law not to include any gossip about her in it. But Sarah included an unflattering anecdote, saying she got a verruca after wearing a pair of shoes she borrowed from Diana - causing the rt. William wedding snub In , Fergie was snubbed from the royal wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge after being unceremoniously left off the guest list.The wedding came a year after she was caught up in a sting set up by a journalist in which she appeared to ask for and accept , in cash in exchange for access to her ex-husband Prince Andrew.Speaking to Town and Country Magazine she said: I didn’t think I was probably worthy to go to their wedding. I took myself to Thailand, actually, to be far away from it so that I could try and heal.”But she bore no ill will towards her nephew William and said previously: I think Diana would be so proud of her son... I really love the feeling that Diana and I both werenapost there. Harryaposs invitationHowever, by the time Williamaposs younger brother Prince Harry married Meghan Markle in , the tide had begun to turn.And Fergie did bag an invite to the big day - marking ato the royal fold. In later years, she of course took her place alongside he royals at the weddings of Beatrice and Eugenie. Balmoral Despite Fergieaposs frosty relationship with Prince Philip, she is said to have remained on good terms with the Queen. And this year she appeared to be back in the royal inner circle by spending time with Her Majesty and other royals at Balmoral. According to royal expert Angela Levin, this made Fergie happy and feel assheaposs back in the crowd. Praise for the Queen And showing her gratitude to the Queen, Sarah has given her some high praise indeed. Speaking on the Tea with Twiggy podcast earlier this year, she said she admires the way Her Majesty is so modern and flexible. She said: I think to myself that honestly my mother-in-law has been more of a mother to me than my mother. I absolutely think there is no greater mentor because from a little girl to now, the consistency of Her Majesty has been a great honour and makes me want to cry. title: handcuffed british man held hostage
story: Handcuffed British man held hostage for eight days in Italy is freed by policeA -year-old man from the UK was on holiday in Italy when he was kidnapped, the Carabinieri police said the day after he was released during a raid in Monte San GiustoThe man was allegedly held hostage in Monte San Giusto, Italy Image: Getty Images EyeEmByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A British tourist was held hostage barefoot and handcuffed for eight days before he was released in a police raid. The man, whose identity has not been made public, was held in a darkened room and fed sporadically, the Carabinieri police said. He was able to use some kind of code to tell his family he was being held hostage while calling them with the ransom request, it has been reported. They then contacted the police who located the -year-old in Monte San Giusto, near the city of Macerata in central Italy,  hours later. On Wednesday afternoon Italian police said they surrounded the apartment of the alleged kidnappers - who had demanded €,for his release - before safely securing the Brit.  Yesterday the Italian force said that the young man had been on holiday in Italy when he was kidnapped. Three of his alleged kidnappers were Italian, while the fourth was Moroccan. They were reportedly arrested and remanded in custody in a prison near the city of Ancona. The young manaposs release was secured via a joint operation between the Carabinieri and the National Crime Agency. It is unclear why the amount of money demanded was relatively small, given the wealth of the British manaposs family.His family, who are fairly wealthy, received a message from him and contacted the British police and the NCA, who in turn contacted the Carabinieri, Colonel Nicola Candido, who was also involved in the operation, said, thereported. Within  hours, we had located the apartment in which he was being held prisoner. The raid took place at  on Wednesday. We surrounded the apartment block, arrested the captors, and released the hostage. The British man had been in Italy since June, he said. Colonel Massimiliano Mengasini, who was also involved in the operation, said the man was found in a darkened room with furniture pushed up against the wall. The man was exhausted but slowly recovering, he added. Sean Kelly, operations manager for the NCA’s Anti Kidnap and Extortion Unit , said: “We have been working closely with the Italian authorities since the kidnap of a British man was reported. “NCA officers in Italy and specialists from AKEU, working together with UK policing, have been providing close support to the Carabinieri Police as part of its ongoing investigation. “We are pleased that this incident has been resolved successfully.”  Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside uks cape canaveral remote
story: Exclusive: Inside UKs Cape Canaveral - the remote Shetland island with its own spaceportBeam me up, Scots! Le is tough on Unst, Britain’s most northerly inhabited island, but it could soon become the site of Britain’s first venture into space from its own territory. Ready for blast-off...Mirrorman Martin Fricker stands on the proposed launch site area Image: Jonathan BuckmasterByMartin Fricker:,  Oct | commentsWise-crackers on a remote Scottish island set to be the new Cape Canaveral have already come up with a slogan: “One wee step for man, one giant leap for McMankind”. Unst, Britain’s most northerly inhabited island, is closer to Norway than Aberdeen and home to fewer than . It has one pub, one hotel, one school, three shops, a lone bus route and no police station or hospital. Located further north than Moscow, sheep outnumber locals and the nearest railway station is in Bergen, Norway. Here le is tough, with an average temperature of C, near-constant gales and just five hours of winter daylight. Yet Unst could soon become the site of Britain’s first venture into space from its own territory. Have your say on this story in the comment section Edinburgh rocket company Skyrora announced this week it had signed a deal to launch satellites from the former Saxa Vord radar base on the island. It wants to send its -metre -ton XL rocket into space from  with up to  launches a year by . Crucially, the SaxaVord Spaceport is expected to create  jobs locally. Not surprisingly it is the talk of the island. At its peak in , during the herring boom, Unst had a population of , but its fortunes declined with the closure of the radar early warning station in .  Hundreds lost their jobs and left the island, creating a knock-on effect for the local economy.In the “capital”, Baltasound, two miles from Saxa Vord, Victoria Mouat, , runs Victoria’s VintageTea Rooms.She moved to Unst  years ago from her native Devon and hopes the spaceport will bring in much-needed trade. She said: “When I first arrived here the island was thriving, thanks to the RAF. “There were social events and re- gattas. There was even an Oktoberfest. “But when the base shut people left in droves, especially young families. “We have an ageing population so I’m really willing the spaceport to succeed because it should bring in new families.”  The mum of four went on: “In summer this is the greatest place on earth. We have hardly any crime and most of us leave our doors unlocked. I genuinely don’t know where my door key is. “But it’s a dferent story in winter. After October we hardly see any visitors.“The weather is bad and it’s only light from am to pm. I just hope it doesn’t put people off coming to work here.“Our northerly location is our claim to fame now but being home to the UK spaceport is even bigger. It’s so exciting.”  Unst, which measures  miles by three, may not boast Cape Canaveral’s tropical climate but it does have one crucial thing in common – its isolation and a “clear run” to space. Rockets must be launched away from urban areas and cannot overfly towns, villages or even oil rigs. From Unst they can head directly north over the Arctic Circle before leaving the earth’s atmosphere. Its northern latitude also means more satellites pass overhead than anywhere  on earth, making it an ideal spot for downloading data from space. At Unst’s only pub, the Balta Light, barmaid Yvonne Thomson, , is confident the spaceport will boost the local economy. She said: “It will bring in the tourists and they will be looking for somewhere to drink. Anything that attracts more visitors is a good thing. “In the longer term, new employees will be bringing their children here which means the school can survive.”  At first sight it is hard to believe Saxa Vord will be launching rockets in a matter of months. New US and Scottish flags fly alongside shiny plastic signs announcing the futuristic site is “under construction”. But just feet away, sheep wander in the howling wind and drizzle through what remains of the RAF base. However, spaceport boss Frank Strang insists plans for a  launch remain on track. The former RAF pilot said: “I’m % confident the first UK orbital launch will take off here next year.” The country-music-loving entrepreneur admits that at first glance Unst is an unlikely frontrunner in the new space race. But plans are in hand for an eco-resort to house visitors and scientists coming to the spaceport.  Get all the latest news straight to your inbox.to one of the Mirroraposs newsletters The -year-old said: “When I first mooted the idea with the local council they thought it was an April Fool. “People of my age think of the old space race but we’re now in the new space race where satellites the size of a teapot cost as little as £,. “On average we all use satellites  times a day in our everyday lives, from cashpoints to mobile phones to GPS. “The UK is ideally placed to be a frontrunner in the new space race and Unst is the perfect spot.” Surprisingly, Frank says there are as many weather windows to launch on the island as there are at sunny Cape Canaveral. “You need a three-hour window of winds under  knots,” he said.“We looked at Met Office data going back a decade and it showed that in spring and autumn we have those windows on % of days. The first rocket is due to be launched from Lamba Ness, a bird-watching spot a mile from the tiny settlement of Haroldswick. Access is via a single-track road where sheep and Shetland ponies wander freely. But plans are under way to build a new road to accommodate the cranes and lorries that carry the rockets. In a reassuring sign of the times, the spaceport is also aiming to be the world’s greenest launch site. Skyrora plans to fuel its rockets with Ecosene, which is made from waste-plastic, preventing more than , tons of un-recyclable plastic going to landfill by . As we leave Unst on the ferry, mph winds howl across the hills and the rain is horizontal as the first early winter storm of  blasts in. It begs the question: Will  really be the year this remote outpost goes up, Unst and away  Just watch this space. story: Men enjoying daily dogging parties in bushes next to Big Baps motorway cafeSharon Wherrett has criticised the doggers for leaving the bushes at Junction  in Brighouse, Yorkshire in a mess and forcing tired lorry drivers to find somewhere  to parkThe Big Baps cafe is close to a popular sex spot Image: Yorkshire LiveByPhoebe Fuller:,  Oct | commentsMen are dogging in the bushes beside a roadside cafe called Big Baps.Sharon Wherrett says her business is being blighted by the al-fresco lovers, who used the shrubbery at Junction  in Brighouse, Yorkshire as a meeting point. Each morning the exasperated caterer sees two or three doggers while sheaposs helping lorry drivers to refuel, Yorkshire Live reported. She claims the men come aposfrom Manchesterapos and sometimes so many people turn up thereaposs no room for lorry drivers to park in the layby. If you came and had breakfast at our cafe youaposd see two or three doggers, guaranteed, she said.  Most people think itaposs funny but itaposs actually really seedy. Thereaposs a hotel  yards up the road, Iaposm sure they would appreciate the business. Itaposs massive. title: meredith kercher familys years torment
story: Meredith Kercher family’s years of torment and complicated relationship with Amanda KnoxThe mysterious death of John Kercher, who was found collapsed in a road in January , has only added to the familys heartache over the horrendous murder of his daughterMeredith Kercher, aged , with her dad John who died in January last year Image: Daily MirrorByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsWhen John Kercher was last year found collapsed in the street, it became the latest tragedy to befall a family caught in a never-ending limbo of grief. The loving father had been tormented for more than a decade by the horrendous murder of his daughter, Meredith - with key questions surrounding the infamous case remaining unanswered to this day. In January last year, the -year-old died in hospital after being found in the road near his Croydon home with two fractured legs, a broken arm and a head injury.In yet another cruel blow to his family, this week a coroner said he was unable to sayJohn was killed in a hit-and-run - with police unable to establish why he was on the road.In a book about Meredithaposs murder, the grief-stricken dad spoke movingly about the stark possibility the Kerchers may never know what happened in her final hours. This is how the family was rocked by the murder trial and subsequent acquittal that made headlines around the world - and why they have a complicated relationship with Meredithaposs exonerated flatmate, Amanda Knox. aposBeautul, caringapos daughter stabbed  times Described by her father as beautul, intelligent and caring, Meredith - from Coulsdon, Surrey - was murdered on November , , during an exchange trip to Italy. Sickeningly, the -year-oldaposs body was found with  stab wounds on the bedroom floor of her apartment in Perugia. Her throat had been cut and an autopsy revealed evidence of sexual assault. John, who was a national newspaper journalist, later recalled how he first discovered his daughter was dead after ringing up a news desk to find out about reports of a British student killed in Perugia.I drop the phone. I do not believe it, he wrote in the Daily Mail.There has to be a mistake. I refuse to let the facts sink in. I repeat it over and over to myself: ‘Not beautul Meredith... Not beautul Meredith.apos  In a case that became a media storm, Meredithaposs housemate Amanda Knox was twice convicted and twice acquitted of her murder and spent four years in prison along with her former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito. Another man, Rudy Guede, was also convicted of murder and was released in December last year after serving a -year sentence. Explaining the sensational acquittal, court adviser Gennaro Marasca said none of the evidence demonstrated that either Knox or Sollecito was present at the crime scene. He added that no biological traces ... could be attributed to them in the room of the murder or on the body of the victim, where in contrast numerous traces were found attributable to Guede.Familyaposs torment over aposstark possibilityapos of never seeing justiceIn the years since, Knox, , has furiously slammed the handling of the case and her utterly unjustied treatment. The Kerchers, meanwhile, have kept a lower profile as they struggle to get answers over what really happened the night Meredith was murdered.  Speaking on the tenth anniversary of her death, sister Stephanie said the pain and helplessness never ceases.She told MailOnline : It is dficult to come terms with not knowing exactly what happened that night, as whether you believe the guilt or innocence of the accused there are still contradictions and discrepancies in the judgeaposs summary.Nor have we heard anything more of a further investigation into who  they think may have been involved. Rudy Guede ... was convicted on the basis that he did not act alone, however, with no one  on trial or convicted it does of course raise questions for us as a family and anyone following the case. In his memoir, Meredith: Our Daughter’s Murder And The Heartbreaking Quest For The Truth, John revealed his pain that the courtroom drama had overshadowed the le of his little girl. In a moving portrait, he paid tribute to her jokes, her wicked one-liners and her laughter - revealing how following his orce from we Arline in , he was comforted by a voicemail from Meredith singing Whitney Houston’s I Will Always Love You down the phone. Yet the familyaposs torment was still painfully raw. We are still waiting for justice for our daughter and sister, he wrote. [We] have to face up to the stark possibility that we might never have a satisfactory picture of what unfolded in Perugia on that terrible November night. In the summer of , John suffered a stroke which he speculated could have been related to the stress of the criminal investigation and draining trips to Italy. Last January, he was found yards from his front door collapsed on the pavement. Scotland Yard initially said John died in a suspected hit-and-run, but later said he had died of a fall. An inquest into John’s death heard the freelance journalist was found by passers-by near his home in Croydon, south London, on a “dark, wet and windy” night in mid-January last year. He was “conscious but confused” and did not know why he was on the ground, the court heard. A Kercher family spokesman said at the time of John’s death: “We loved him dearly and he is going to be very sorely missed.” Knoxaposs aposcomplicatedapos relationship with Kerchers The Kerchersapos search for answers has at times brought them into conflict with Knox, with relatives slamming her inappropriate behaviour following her acquittal.The American has built up a huge media profile - releasing a memoir that reportedly earned her £.million, taking part in a Netflix documentary about the case and most recently hosting a series of podcasts including The Truth About True Crime. In , she ed to Italy to participate in a conference about wrongful convictions, sparking a rare statement from the Kerchers branding her actions inappropriate and very painful.The Kerchers’ lawyer, Francesco Maresca, told the: “All these insistences and appearances are only ever done to keep the attention on herself.“The murder is a tragic memory for the Kercher family, they lost their daughter and sister in such a terrible way. It’s also an injustice for them as they still don’t know the full truth.” He added of her involvement in the conference: “It’s unjustied because her process was not a classic case of ‘judicial error’. There was a swing in the decisions: some judges decided one way, and others in another way.” Previously Knox has said she would like to meet the Kercher family and visit Meredithaposs grave - but was warned by sister Stephanie to stay away.  She is currently pregnant with her first child with husband Christopher Robinson after suffering a miscarriage in May. Speaking to RTÉ Radio  in August, Knox admitted she has kept her distance from Meredithaposs parents, saying: “To this day, I can’t tell youthey know that I’m innocent or not.”  Given the fact that I don’t know that fact, I also understand that me even approaching them is a potential cause of great distress to their family and a dredging up of terrible memories.”She added: “I understand that the Kerchers have gone through an incredibly traumatic journey, not just from the tragic loss of Meredith but also through the incredibly confusing trial that they had to experience and go through and the feeling of being denied a sense of closure because of the outcome of the case. “Given that understanding, I also know that they have a complicated relationship with me.” Comment MORE ON Meredith KercherAmanda KnoxRudy GuedeRaffaele SollecitoMurder" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: people urged retested after pcrs
story: Testing suspended at UK lab after up to , given wrong negative Covid resultImmensa Health was handed a £ million contract and runs a laboratory in Wolverhampton which health officials said gave , people incorrect results between September  and October " content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _RGP_MDM_Swab_.jpg" width"" "" The issues happened at a Department for Health and Social CareImage: Rowan GrfithsByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsTens of thousands of Brits have been wrongly told they don’t have Covid due to problems with NHS Test and Trace. PCR swabs from a number of testing sites have been ing negative results to people who had the virus due to errors at a major laboratory in the Midlands. The public have now been told to get retested while close contacts with symptoms are also advised to get a PCR check. It is the latest controversy around the bungled NHS Test and Trace programme which has seen the Government hand multimillion contracts to private firms to run much of the system. Immensa Health was handed a £ million contract and runs a laboratory in Wolverhampton which health officials said gave , people incorrect results between September  and October . Have you been impacted by unreliable testing at the lab  Email webnews@mirror  Most of these results were for people in South West England, prompting fears of spike in the region. Dr Will Welfare, incident director at the UK Health Security Agency, said: “We have recently seen a rising number of positive lateral flow test results subsequently testing negative on PCR. “As a result of our investigation, we are working with NHS Test and Trace and the company to determine the laboratory technical issues which have led to inaccurate PCR results being issued to people. We have immediately suspended testing at this laboratory while we continue the investigation.” Dr Kit Yates, expert at the University of Bath, said: “There’s been a concerted effort to highlight what’s been going on with these strange results for a while now in the hope that someone would investigate. “We now know , people are believed to have been given  negatives, but this doesn’t even come near to the cost of the mistake.  “Many of these people will have been forced into school or work potentially infecting others. This could be part of the reason behind some of the recent rises we’ve seen.” The testing site had previously made headlines after staff were filmed fighting, sleeping, fighting and rolling around on the floor. The contract was handed to Immensa without a standard tender process and according to Companies House the firm only appears to have existed since May just after the start of the pandemic. Andrea Riposati, CEO of Immensa Health Clinic Ltd, said: “We are fully collaborating with UKHSA on this matter. “Quality is paramount for us. We have proudly analysed more than . million samples for NHS Test and Trace.  “We do not wish this matter or anything  to tarnish the amazing work done by the UK in this pandemic.” West Berkshire Council released a statement calling on those who used its Newbury Showground testing site to book another PCR check. The mass testing site in Chieveley, West Berkshire, is one of those affected by the errors at the Immensa lab.  It said Newbury Showground “had results sent out that may have incorrectly shown as negative for Covid-”. It continued: “After receiving reports from local residents in recent weeks that there were concerns about the accuracy of test results from the site, we passed these concerns onto the DHSC for further investigation. “The DHSC has now confirmed that a number of sites nationally may have been affected by this issue, including the one at Newbury Showground.” Those who received a negative result for a PCR test between October  and , as well as their close contacts, were “strongly” encouraged by the local authority to take another test. Dr Welfare, of the UK Has, added: “There is no evidence of any faults with lateral flow tests or PCR test kits themselves and the public should remain confident in using them and in other laboratory services currently provided. “If you get a positive LFD test, it’s important to make sure that you then get a follow up PCR test to confirm you have COVID-. “If you have symptoms of COVID-, self-isolate and take a PCR test. story: Pub landlord puts cheeky sign outside after noise complaint from neighbourA pub landlord placed a sign outside the venue telling its guests to "whisper" while in the beer garden as a neighbour has "nothing better to do than run to the council and whinge"The pub hit back at a nearby neighbour Image: GoogleByOllie LeitelmayerLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA landlord placed a sarcastic sign outside their pub in response to a whingeing neighbour who lodged an official noise complaint with the local council.The Victoria pub in Tilehurst, Reading, posted an image of the message on Facebook which set out the venueaposs new garden rules for those who visit, Berkshire Live reports.It read: Dear customers, can we please ask that you whisper whilst in our garden. This is due to the fact that we have some neighbours that forget they live next door to a pub and not a library and have nothing better to do than run to the council and whinge.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. The pub regularly hosts live music events, and is open until pm on weeknights and midnight on weekends. Reading Borough Council procedure requires the complainant to fill out a noise diary to indicate when issues arise with a commercial property, andthe noise continues, officers would be sent to assess the situation and take actionrequired. The pub has not responded to Berkshire Liveaposs request to comment on the situation. Councillor Helen Manghnani, who represents Tilehurst, says she sometimes visits the pub but had not been aware of the sign. She said: Like everything in todayaposs world, things seem to be louder, music, traffic and even people intend to talk in higher pitched voices. It is dficult for those in senior years to deal with ultra-loud noises and to be quite frank, many of the complaints I receive revolve around loud music and late night garden parties. She added: With regards to the sign, it could have been a little more understanding, leaving off the sentence referring to living next door to a pub. We don’t know how long people have lived there, whether the pub came first or the house. title: queen master silence comes andrew
story: Queen is master of silence when it comes to Andrew - but not when shes after a decoyThe Royals sudden interest in our sweltering planet seems very convenient for Prince Andrew, dont you think, asks Liam GilliverThe noise surrounding Andrew’s legal battle has quickly been muffled by the Queen’s rare anger towards Russia and China’s green efforts Image: Getty ImagesopinionByLiam Gilliver:,  Oct This week the Royal Family have turned green and shed light on the dooming subject of climate change. Prince William blasted billionaires Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk over their race to leave the planetto travel around space.He urged them to focus on saving Earth and hailed them for having “great minds”. However, he failed to criticise the wealthy duo for how their companies and lestyle play a signicant part in the climate crisis.Meanwhile, the Queen was “overheard” slamming world leaders who “talk but don’t do” when it comes to climate action, ahead of COP.The monarch’s private comment was coincidentally recorded by a journalist and quickly made headlines around the world.  And it’s understandable why. The Queen - renowned for staying silent and dressing in impartiality - suddenly having a rather strong opinion on such a political issue is quite the story.And while there’s a blatant sense of hypocrisy about a family preaching about the climate while sitting on mined jewels, flying private jets and running multiple estates the Royal Family’s sudden interest in Mother Nature also feels like a transparent attempt to ert people’s attention.  From what  Or who  Well, Prince Andrew, of course. This week was the Duke of Yorkaposs pre-trial hearing as part of the -year-oldaposs sexual abuse allegations. In , Virginia Giuffre claimed the Duke of York abused her on a number of occasions when she was just . Vigorously denying the allegations in his infamous  Newsnight interview, Andrew said he had no recollection of ever meeting her and claimed the photo of the two together had been doctored.But the noise surrounding Andrew’s legal battle has quickly been muffled by coverage of William’s Earthshot initiative and the Queen’s rare anger towards Russia and China’s green efforts.The Met also quietly announced it was dropping its probe into Andrew, while the Duke is still laying low, playing on Mummy’s horses.So while the Queen and William are sweating about the planet, Andrew is staying cool. story: Residents wake up to find homes, cars and streets blanketed in strange white powderPeople living in Preston Brook, Cheshire, faced damaged cars and were told to toss their vegetable patches after the glass-like material blanketed the areaResidents in Preston Brook, near Runcorn woke up to this mysterious white powder covering their carsByMilo ClayAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Oct | commentsResidents in a small village were left puzzled when they woke up to find their homes, cars and streets blanketed in a strange white powder. The powder, which reportedly came from a nearby manufacturing plant, baffled locals in Preston Brook, near Runcorn, on October .The road is near the Saint Gobain Isover manufacturing plant, which produces mineral wool insulation, CheshireLive reports. Residents are worried about their pets and wildle ingesting the powder as some fear it contains glass. Dave Espley, , woke up to find his car and the street he lives on covered in the substance and said it looked like it has snowed.  He also said a number of cars have been damaged and residents with vegetable gardens have been told to throw their home-grown produce away. He said: The issue is what it has discharged and whether itaposs safe for wildle and pets, itaposs also very abrasive so itaposs causing all sorts of issues with peopleaposs cars as well. It looked like it snowed when we got up in the morning, literally everything was covered in it and the main concern was wondering what it is.  He added: Weaposve been told it is  per cent glass so apparently it will not dissolve as soon as it rains. Iaposm not quite sure how they are going to fully recty it because itaposs all over the fields as well. I know people have vegetable patches and they have been advised to chuck it all away. You can still see it all over the road outside the plantitself, it looks like frost. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information atwww.mirror email .The Environment Agency has been round and so has the Isover plant manager and apologised and I think he was having a worse day than anyone . The main concern here is what is in it andit is potentially toxic. Weaposve been told itaposs not harmful and not to eat it, but obviously we are concerned about pets and wildle. Dave also said that due to the abrasive substance, it has damaged a number of cars on the street and valets have been arranged to help remove the powder from peopleaposs cars. He added: Theyaposre trying toand theyaposve booked appointments with car cleaners to come round and clean all the cars, I had to use the hose to get it off of my car. It was absolutely covered, thankfully we didnapost rub it, but I know other people who have taken their car to a car wash and this stuff has caused real damage. I am assuming this is what they use to clean out the chimney as it is real abrasive stuff. A neighbour of mine has said their windscreen is covered in scratches because he took it to a car wash. They have been around valeting peopleaposs cars and doing a big clean up as they can. Itaposs been reported to the environmental agency and there is a big clear-up happening at the minute. A spokesperson for Isover said that the dust is nothing to worry about and apologised to residents over the situation. The statement read: There was a small release of dust from the vent ducting when we restarted the plant after a short planned shutdown. Our Plant Manager has been visiting local residents over the last few days to explain the situation, apologise and to reassure residents that there is nothing to worry about at all. Where needed we have also arranged for professional cleaning to take place and we have been in dialogue with the Environment Agency who are fully aware of the release. We take great care to be a responsible business and take issues like this very seriously indeed.” A spokesperson for the Environment Agency said: We are working with the company to offer advice and guidance under our regulatory role. story: Schoolgirl, , told to stop eating sugary snacks by doctor actually had cancerLyra Cassell, , from Allerton, Liverpool, was initially told she should reduce the amount of sugar she was eating after finding two lumps, but after further tests scans, it was revealed she had an aggressive form of cancerLyra Cassell, , from Allerton was initially told to reduce the amount of sugar she is eating after finding two lumps Image: Family handoutByCharlotte HadfieldShiler Mahmoudi:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA schoolgirl was told to stop eating sugar snacks and drinks by a doctor when in actual fact, she had cancer. Lyra Cassell, , from Allerton, Liverpool, found a lump in her groin at the end of August and asked to see a doctor. Her mum, Hayley, says they were told the lump was a hernia, and that they could not get a hospital appointment for months due to an NHS backlog that has been caused by the pandemic.Hayley told the Liverpool Echo : She had a hernia as a baby so we thought it was nothing to worry about. Then we went for a walk in Garston Park and she went aposIaposve got this lump on my neck.apos It was on the side of her neck and it was quite big. I thought aposthataposs not right Lyraapos and I phoned the doctors again. Following her second appointment with a nurse, Lyra was referred for an appointment the hospital and a few days later she had her bloods taken by her GP. Hayley said: [The doctor] phoned me on the Tuesday morning to tell me she was anaemic and to stop giving her sweets and fizzy drinks. They said sheaposs not diabetic but her blood sugar levels are slightly high. However, two weeks later, Lyra went for an ultrasound appointment followed by a biopsy and further blood tests, and on September  received the devastating news that she had acute lymphoblastic leukaemia. She started receiving chemotherapy the next day. Mum Hayley said: Everything was going well for her. The fit and healthy Belvedere Academy student had recently smashed her GCSEs and was running five times a week for the Liverpool Harriers And Athletic Club. Hayley, , said: [Lyra] works in Ginoaposs restaurant in town part-time on the reception and she also taught dance in Liverpool College to four- year olds, so she was really busy and she was loving it. She was saying she was tired but we just put it down to working and going out with her friends. Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia is a type of cancer that affects white blood cells. It progresses quickly and aggressively and requires immediate treatment.  Hayley said: Lyraaposs first question was aposwill I lose my hair apos They explained to us that it will be a very dficult process of at least two years. It feels like itaposs someone  this has happened to - this doesnapost happen to us. Itaposs just horrendous. Two weeks ago I had a normal, and what we thought was a healthy teenager, ready to smash her A-levels and go out clubbing and do all the things we did as a   year old, and now everything is a train wreck. Lyra is currently undergoing treatment and has recently been diagnosed with steroid-induced diabetes. If Lyra hadnapost found the lump on her neck when she did, Hayley fears how long it would have been before she found out she had cancer. With this in mind, Hayley is keen to raise awareness and encourage others to get checked out at the first sign of symptoms.In a bid to help the family during this time, Lyraaposs running coach and family friend Jayne Teare has set up a Go Fund Me page.In a message on the page Jayne said: Lyra’s unique love of le and people shines through with most people she meets. She is warm, funny, goofy, caring, determined and very kind. She and her family are terried by what this new future holds and the upset it will have on Lyra and her loved ones. The journey will be long and dficult but we have to focus on the light at the end of the tunnel. Currently, le for Lyra is tough as she undergoes extensive chemotherapy and deals with the complications that this can cause. Any support or help you can offer would be greatly appreciated. news uk-news sir-david-amess-inside-le-"David Amess: Essex Police confirm death of Conservative MPByClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct Tory MP Sir David Amess has tragically died after being stabbed multiple times while meeting local residents at constituency surgery in a church in Essex. The -year-old, who had been an MP for  years, was holding his regular Friday surgery for constituents at the Belfairs Methodist Church, Leigh-on-Sea. Police have arrested a -year-old man on suspicion of murder and a kne was recovered at the scene. His death comes five years after Labour MP Jo Cox was murdered as she arrived to host a surgery in her Batley and Spen constituency in June . As tributes poured in, Downing Street lowered the Union flag to half-mast as a mark of respect to the popular Southend West MP. While Prime Minister Boris Johnsonaposs we Carrie said he was a true gent.Taking to Twitter to express her shock and send her thoughts to Sir Davidaposs we Julia, she said: Absolutely devastating news about Sir David Amess. He was hugely kind and good. An enormous animal lover and a true gent. This is so completely unjust. Thoughts are with his we and their children.Labour leader Keir Starmer said: Horric and deeply shocking news. Thinking of David, his family and his staff.Deemed on of the longest-serving MPs, below is an outline of who Sir David was and where he came from. Who was Sir David Amess  Sir David was born in Plaistow, Essex, now known as Newham in London on March , . As a child he attended St Anthonyaposs Junior and Infant School, then St Bonaventureaposs Catholic School in Forest Gate before moving on to the College of Technology. His higher education took place at the Faculty of Science and Technology of Bournemouth University, where he got a bachelors in economics and government. He taught at a primary school in Bethnal Green and had some experience as underwriter and recruitment consultant but he quickly turned to to public service in politics.  Family le The MP and his we Julia, who worked for him as a part-time caseload worker have four daughters and a son. His daughter, Katie, is an actress based in LA and recently starred in Captain America. Political le The Conservative MP served as an MP for  years, initially in Basildon from  before he took on the role of representing Southend West from . He regarded his main interests and areas of expertise as animal welfare and pro-le issues. But his campaigning efforts in the House of Commons in recent years were most closely associated with his campaign to see Southend awarded city status. A long-term eurosceptic, he was part of the Leave Means Leave pro-Brexit campaign during the EU referendum. He never held a ministerial role and was vocal about a whole range of issues, from animal rights to campaigning against abortion.During his time in parliament he sponsored a string of bills including the AbortionBill , the Protection Against Cruel Tethering Actand the Warm Homes Bill, which passed into law in December  as the Warm Homes and Energy Conservation Act, according to his website. The two main issues he had at heart were animal rights and pro-le issues. Sir David has not been shy in ensuring questions he asks Government ministers also include his long-running campaign to make Southend a city. In December , he secured an adjournment debate in the Commons specically on the campaign and he told MPs: I am not messing around. We have got it from the Prime Minister that Southend is going to become a city - and it will become a city.  As a strident supporter of the British monarchy, Sir David saw another opportunity in November  as the Commons considered plans for the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee next year. He asked for a new statue of the Queen and for a city status competition to ensure Southend is finally elevated. In March , Sir David repeated his statue calls - insisting the Queen deserved one for being a great monarch.  His campaign for a memorial to Dame Vera Lynn on the White Clfs of Dover also won support from a minister in May this year. He was well known in Southend West for his support for local causes and every year held the aposannual centenariansapos tea partyapos to celebrate constituents who had turned . Away from his campaigning, Sir David announced in December  that he would run to be one of the three deputy speakers in the House of Commons.He ultimately missed out and continued with his support for Brexit and working in his constituency.He recently wrote of how MPs had received security advice about holding surgeries, and how attacks had spoilt the great British tradition of the voters meeting politicians. In Ayes  Ears: A Survivoraposs Guide to Westminster - which was published in November - he wrote about Jo Coxaposs murder and how she had been attacked in the most barbaric fashion imaginable. Sir David also wrote about the machete attack on Nigel Jones MP, which resulted in his aide Andy Penningtonaposs death as he tried to protect him. And the Essex politician mentioned he had experienced nuisance from the odd member of the general public at his own property. He said most MPs had changed the way they interacted with voters, and the Commons authorities took the threats members faced very seriously.  Achievements Sir Amess was knighted in the  New Year Honours for political and public service. He was also given the Animal Welfare and Environment Champion award at the Dods Charity Champion Awards in  for his commitment to animal warfare. Ahead of his death being announced, Councillor John Lamb, who was the scene of the horric attack, heaped praise on the MP, who he called a family man. Heaposs always trying to help people and especially refugees heaposs tried to help. Heaposs a very amicable person and he does stick by his guns, he says what he believes and he sticks by it. Tributes to apostrue gentapos and a aposgreat manapos Tributes from across the political spectrum have flooded in for Sir David. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has said all our hearts are filled with shock and sadness. Mr Johnsonaposs we, Carrie, said she was devastated. Absolutely devastating news about Sir David Amess. He was hugely kind and good, she said on Twitter. An enormous animal lover and a true gent. This is so completely unjust. Former Conservative prime minister Theresa May tweeted: Heartbreaking to hear of the death of Sir David Amess. A decent man and respected Parliamentarian, killed in his own community while carrying out his public duties. A tragic day for our democracy. My thoughts and prayers are with Davidaposs family. Former prime minister Tony Blair said he was shocked and horried by the murder of Sir David Amess. David and I came into Parliament together in , he said in a statement. Though on opposite political sides I always found him a courteous, decent and thoroughly likeable colleague who was respected across the House. This is a terrible and sad day for our democracy. Meanwhile, Jo Coxaposs widower Brendan said: My thoughts and love are with Davidaposs family. They are all that matter now. This brings everything back. story: Stepmum battered boy leaving him leless in hallway and then organised her birthdayDad Thomas Hughes, , and step-mum Emma Tustin, , are accused of murdering Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, from Solihull, West Midlands, with the trial heard at Coventry Crown CourtArthur Labinjo-Hughes, six, was found unresponsive at a home in Solihull, on June  last year Image: BPM MediaByCarl JacksonMatthew CooperCricket Trends Writer:,  Oct A step-mum accused of murder texted someone about party balloons around the time she allegedly delivered a fatal blow to a six-year-old. Dad Thomas Hughes, , and step-mum Emma Tustin, , are accused of mistreating Arthur Labinjo-Hughes before he suffered an un-survivable brain injury at his home in Cranmore Road, Solihull, West Midlands, on June  .The young boy died in hospital in the early hours of the following day, Birmingham Mail reported. Hughes and Tustin both deny murder. Yesterday in court on the sixth day of the trial jurors were played CCTV footage taken in the living room of the family home on June , when Arthur allegedly endured the fatal injury.  They were also shown texts between the Hughes and Tustin from that day, including a photo sent from the woman in which Arthur appears to be crying. From the home Tustin texted Hughes, who was out at the shops, multiple times, writing that the boy was grabbing walls and door and throwing himself down just before pm. They discussed whether a mark on his face was bruising before Tustin sent Hughes an audio clip of Arthur crying followed by a text saying: Still at it. The prosecution showed a clip of the woman leaving the living room for about a minute, during which time they contend she dealt Arthur the fatal blow. Jonas Hankin QC told the court that around this time Tustin texted the aposballoon ladyapos about her birthday decorations for an upcoming party. At .pm Tustin messaged Hughes: Just copped me in the stomach he has thrown himself all over the floor wonapost get up for s*** Iaposve shut the door on him.  A minute later she took a picture on her phone showing Arthur lying down in the hallway. The court was played living room footage showing Tustin walking into the kitchen before ing while looking at her phone and then walking into the hallway. She s carrying Arthur into the living room, Mr Hankin told the court. His body is limp. She carries Arthur into the kitchen then into the living room and places him on the floor. Arthur appears to be unconscious. His eyes are closed, body is limp. He falls to the left onto the floor. It appears his body is limp. Tustin gets up and goes into the kitchen. The next footage from .pm shows Tustin partially pick Arthur up from the floor and drag him into the hallway. She then reappears and places Arthur on the sofa before walking into the kitchen. Giving evidence in court earlier on Thursday, Tustinaposs hairdresser, Catherine Milhench, said she wished she had called police after seeing Arthur on June  and . Ms Milhench, who works from home and first cut Tustinaposs hair in the summer of , said she met Arthur later that year and he seemed absolutely fine, healthy, a normal boy.  Describing a hair appointment at her home in February , Ms Milhench said of Arthur: He was still, I would say, healthy-looking but not happy. He was made to sit downwith his hands on his knees and not move. Ms Milhench told the court: I just thought heaposs obviously been naughty at home. When you go to other peopleaposs you donapost want your child to misbehave. Answering questions from Mr Hankin, Ms Milhench said at another six-hour hair appointment on June  , Arthur was told by Tustin to stand by and face the front door. Mr Hankin asked Ms Milhench: Throughout the time that she was there in your home, how did she sheinteract with Arthur  The witness answered: Telling him to stand, not to lean on the door, to face the door... not to move. Tustin then went to the bathroom to have her hair washed, Ms Milhench said, adding of Arthur: He was made to come upstairs and face another door upstairs. She said he couldnapost be trusted. Asked for her view of Arthuraposs state during the visit, Ms Milhench said: Deteriorated. You could see his collar bones. He was wearing a pyjama onesie and you could just see his collar bones sticking out.  I didnapost remember that from last time. He had lost weight. Using the phrase like skeletal to describe what Arthuraposs condition made her think of, Ms Milhench said the boy appeared to be drained and weak, adding: It wasnapost nice to see. His legs trying to walk up the stairs would be shaking, like he couldnapost hold himself up. Asked what happened when Hughes arrived at her home to pick up Tustin, Ms Milhench added: He parked on my drive. Tom had himby the scruff, took him out. I remember Arthur falling on the floor. He just collapsed and fell into the car. The court heard Tustin ed to complete her hair appointment on June , arriving at around .am. During the visit, Ms Milhench said Tustin and Hughes were constantly swearing at Arthur like a game of tennis, with Tustin going on to claim that Arthur was being pressure-pointed. Ms Milhench said she had suggested Arthur should be sent to live with his grandmother, but was told that would be what he wants and would allow him to win. The court was also told that Ms Milhenchaposs partner, Tobias Jarman, snuck a drink of water to Arthur without Tustin and Hughes knowing. Mr Jarman, who said Arthur looked malnourished and had cracked lips, told the court: I tried to reassure him. I said, aposyou have not got to be scared of me in any wayapos. He look petried. It was not the normal glow you see in a kidaposs eyes of that age. It looked like there was fear ingrained inside of there. Hughes and Tustin deny murder. Tustin has admitted one count of child cruelty but has denied further charges of the same offence. Hughes also denies child cruelty offences.
