story: Mum says  teens at same college suffered Tourettes-like ticks from nowhereMadison Collins, , began suffering from head jerks and ticks, which mum Melanie says seemed to "come from nowhere" in January of this year - with the attacks getting so bad she has ended up in hospital unable to breatheMadison Collins began suffering from head jerks and ticks, which mum Melanie says seemed to come from nowhere Image: Kennedy News and MediaByNia Price:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA teenager reportedly developed Touretteaposs-like ticks at the same time as  other people in her college. Madison Collins began suffering from head jerks and ticks, which mum Melanie says seemed to come from nowhere in January of this year.Melanie, , described how one frightening attack in June left -year-old Madison, known as Madi, unable to breathe and needing hospital treatment. The worried mum said she now fears the ticks are being caught via social media after learning  other girls developed similar symptoms.The manager said Madi is now aposticking every dayapos to the point where sheaposs repeated phrases  times, punched herself and her hands have even locked into place for three hours. Melanie remains sceptical that her daughteraposs sudden condition is caused by social media specically as she questions why boys have been less affected, however she said she aposwouldnapost rule it outapos. She is now speaking out about Madiaposs situation and urging parents with similar experiences to come forward to find its cause. Melanie, of Clacton-on-Sea, Essex, said: [The college] said that they had  girls and one boy that have ticks at the moment. I was relieved. I know thataposs an awful thing to say but hearing that made me know that something has actually happened.  Something is happening to make this happen to girls andI can find a reason for it, I can deal with it better. If somethingaposs happening as a nation, we need to get to the bottom of it. We owe it to our daughters to find out why this is happening and what we can do to make sure it doesnapost happen to other girls her age. I just felt like I wanted to do something and rather than sitting there speculating, I want to find out for myself how big of a problem this is rather than being told aposthis is happeningapos. I want to get people together so we can do something about it. I think thereaposs strength in numbers and rather than this getting pushed under the carpet,I can find other people going through this, we can push this to the government level to get something done about it and get proper research to find what the cause is. Research led by Dr Kirsten Muller-Vahl at the Hannover University Medical School stated that a spike in patients displaying aposticksapos positively correlated to a rise in videos featuring Touretteaposs on sites such as TikTok, YouTube and Instagram.The study claimed the rise in ticks could be viewed as a aposstress reactionapos to societyaposs emphasis on iniduality and aposvaluing their alleged exceptionalityapos, which they say promotes aposattention-seeking behavioursapos. Worried Melanie has read the articles on the subject and also heard the condition linked to stress from the pandemic but she remains unsure what is causing it. However she refuses to rule anything out and called for more people to come forward so that more research can be done.  Melanie said: Online articles are saying that social media sites like TikTok is a probable cause. One of them is that people are going on there to highlight their ticks and thataposs starting off other kids to have it. On my LinkedIn posts there have been comments that have been said about that social media is being looked into as a possible cause, people have said aposmaybe social media is the reason whyapos, thereaposs been a couple of articles as well that have been linked on my LinkedIn post. My gut is telling me that itaposs external. Something has happened which is affecting girls. A lot of people are putting it down to [social media] or the stress of the pandemic but Iaposm not convinced of that because Madi will delete her social media every so often. Andshe feels like sheaposs becoming a bit consumed by social media she will delete it from time to time and will almost hit a reset and then go back to it. When I asked her about her stress levels during the pandemic she wasnapost particularly overly stressed. Iaposm not saying that it hasnapost played a part in it, Iaposm just not convinced she was stressed enough to bring on ticks. But then I donapost know, Iaposm not a medical doctor. I donapost think itaposs social media because I thinkit was social media,it was TikTok, like people are saying, I think boys would be affected. I wouldnapost rule it out. But I just thinkit was social media, it would affect boys as well, particularly as this condition is more prevalent in boys than it is in girls.  Melanie, who described her daughter as aposreliableapos, aposactiveapos and aposfunnyapos said she never had any of these symptoms as a child and from her understanding most children with Touretteaposs usually get recognised by the child is six-years-old. The devoted mum said sheaposs also been told by professionals that normally cases of Touretteaposs are more prevalent in boys. However, in the last  months thereaposs been a massive spike in referrals for girls between the ages of -. Melanie said: It was probably about eight months ago that she started these head ticks where she was jolting her head and they started getting progressively worse. Then she started having almost seizure-type ticks where her eyes would roll in the back of her head. We had to phone the ambulance, sheaposs been to hospital about it twice. They were so bad that she couldnapost breathe properly. It was almost like a seizure but when she was in hospital they confirmed it wasnapost because her vitals were quite normal, so it was just a tick spasm attack. It was frightening to watch. Sheaposs had a few of those. And then the vocal ticks about this time started kicking in as well. Madi says the ticks have had a dramatic effect on her daily le.  Her ticks include clicking noises, neck jerks, punching herself, vocal ticks in which she repeats a phrase repeatedly, sometimes for a whole day, scratching herself and even banging her head against the table. Madi said: When the ticks were small it didnapost really matter and to be honest I put it down to anxiety ticks for quite a long time and I just thought theyaposd go away. And when they got really bad it stopped everything. I used to read a lot and for a few weeks after my ticks got really bad I just couldnapost pick up a book, Iaposd just throw it. And there are still times I do throw my books. Just not as often now, you kind of learn how to deal with it. I wasnapost able to sit through my classes. I was told to leave a lot. I practically wasnapost able to do anything normal anymore. Everything became a lot harder. When I was working at the restaurant, I would have incidents where I would throw a glass on the floor. Then when I was trying to pick it up, I would just put it in my mouth and try to bite down unless someone took it out. There will be days where I can barely walk a few steps without falling over. When Iaposm trying to have a conversation with someone, my vocal ticks can get in the way and they can cause a lot of mishaps. For example, people think Iaposm calling them a b*tch or something. When Iaposm trying to do assessments or exams it can be really hard. I was trying to do an assessment in criminology and my hands locked so I was trying to do it with one hand and it didnapost unlock for three hours after, which is quite painful because itaposs quite a cramping one. Mum-of-three Melanie shared a post on LinkedIn and said that around - parents have contacted her, with around four or five of them saying their children have suddenly developed Touretteaposs.  She said that Madiaposs college have been aposabsolutely brilliantapos and theyaposve kept her included in all the decisions made surrounding her education. Melanie said: She hasnapost been diagnosed with Touretteaposs yet because she had to have symptoms for over a year to get diagnosed. Itaposs walking that fine line of not accepting it but at the same time accepting it because you donapost want her to feel uncomfortable by it. At the moment it looks like Touretteaposs, thataposs what itaposs presenting itself as. It was a lot to get my head around and to be honest itaposs only then when talking to the college that I was realising that other girls are going through this that I thought there must be a cause, andwe can find the reason weaposve got a better chance of finding treatment or a cure. Dr Muller-Vahl et alaposs study claimed teenagers were presenting ticks similar to a popular German YouTuber who demonstrated them in his videos, which have gone viral over the last two years. Suzanne Dobson of Touretteaposs Action, a UK-based charity that researches the condition and supports affected families, suggested in an interview earlier this year that social media may simply be encouraging teenage girls to be more open about their ticks. But she also speculated that gathering more aposlikesapos for demonstrating severe ticks, could be resulting in the girls no longer trying to stop the ticks. Hospitals in the UK claim to have seen an increase in ticks being reported in teenage girls since the pandemic. Great Ormond Street and Evelina Childrenaposs Hospitals each received between four and six referrals of ticks in teenage girls between -. However during the last three months of , this surged to each receiving three to four referrals per week. title: woman told cant pregnant after
story: Woman told she cant get pregnant after discovering she was born without a wombJaclyn Misch, from Michigan, USA has been diagnosed with Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser Type , a rare condition that occurs in females and mainly affects the reproductive systemJaclyn Misch was born without a womb Image: mediadrumworld   Jaclyn MiscByLiana Jacob:,  Oct | commentsA woman who was born without a womb is determined that she will become a mum. Jaclyn Misch, from Michigan, USA, was -years-old when she started to think she had a health issue as she hadnapost had her period yet. After several doctors appointments she was diagnosed with Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-HauserType , a rare condition that occurs in females and mainly affects the reproductive system. Essentially it means that she was born with no womb or cervix, and also has an incomplete vagina. A dilator was used to stretch her vaginal canal so that she could have penetrative sex, but she cannot carry her own child. In , the now -year-old who won the title of Miss Michigan USA , met Jonathan and then married him in .  The couple tried for a baby through IVF and gestational surrogacy, but after three failed embryo transfers they parted ways from their former carrier. They currently have a new gestational carrier that volunteered to potentially carry their baby. I was diagnosed with MRKH when I was sixteen my family physician was concerned I had never started my cycle but since I was lean and athletic, thought this might be the delay, Jaclyn said.  At sixteen years old, I really wanted to pretend that none of this was happening, so thataposs exactly what I did. Iaposd been trying so hard to fit in with my high school friends, but as fate would have it, my diagnosis had a dferent path planned for me. I was now one in , women around the world diagnosed with MRKH Syndrome. The fundamental biological traits that made me a woman, my self-identity and the plans for my future had shted.  I had to use dilators to have sex, I would never have a period and be like my girlfriends and I would never carry a child. I didnapost feel the same as other females and I frankly still donapost. Jaclyn said she kept quiet about the condition for years, not even telling members of her own family. Husband Jonathan helped the wine educator and marketer open up. He encouraged me to enter my first pageant and I won, she continued. I truly feel like I won as a way to use the  to spread awareness about MRKH syndrome. At the time of my diagnosis, there was no social media and the only thing my parents and I could find online about it were a few research articles. I felt confused, scared and angry. I ignored most of my emotion towards it and didnapost want to think about it.  It took me years to come to terms with the diagnoses and fully process. I had to learn to become comfortable in my own skin again for sixteen years of my le I had been conditioned by society and our culture to think I would grow up, get married and have a baby. Jaclyn had long hoped that she would one day become a mum.  I played with baby dolls and dreamt of having a baby bump, she continued. So when the diagnosis came, my self-identity shted and I had to start envisioning a le without the blessing of pregnancy. As far as sexual intercourse goes, I think itaposs important to preface this by saying everything is aposnormalapos down there on the outside. But girls with MRKH have a aposshallowapos vaginal canal, meaning in order to have sexual intercourse you need to self-dilate . Or have surgery to elongate the vaginal canal my doctor and I decided dilation was my best option, as itaposs also the first line of treatment recommended by The American College of Gynaecology.  I didnapost have much of an issue and things went quickly and smoothly. As happy as the couple are together, MRKH has had an affect on their relationship. Iaposve been with my husband Jonathan since  and I have to say that my diagnosis affects our relationship emotionally in our journey to parenthood, Jaclyn said. Seeing our friends get pregnant so fast and easily will always strike a small chord in my mind. Of course, Iaposm happy for them but always wishing to have that ability myself. After our three failed embryo transfers and parting ways with our previous gestational carrier I was a mess. Asking myself what my le purpose is, will we ever have a child of our own  I was completely deflated, and it hit me much harder than Jonathan. Instead of the path to parenthood being joyful and happy ours is stressful, emotional, and draining both mentally and financially. Our journey to parenthood is by far the most challenging. For the longest time, Iaposve seen PGS aposchromosomally normalapos embryos taking on the first time. Iaposve had friends with MRKHget pregnant on their first transfer with their high-quality embryos so naturally, I thought we would too as our embryos were perfectly normal. But that wasnapost the case three times in a row. The waiting period is also extremely dficult. Between transfers, waiting for the two-week pregnancy blood test building up excitement only to be completely deflated with the negative results. Currently, we have a new gestational carrier and are beyond grateful that she and her husband have volunteered to help us start a family. We are in the process of having her screened by our IVF doctor. Jaclyn hopes that others will gain strength from her story. She said: You are never alone so many women have been diagnosed with MRKH from around the world there is an entire network of MRKH sisters waiting for you with encouragement, understanding and support through every phase of MRKH. title: mysterious abandoned afternoon tea bubbles
story: Mysterious abandoned afternoon tea with bubbles and cheese discovered in UK woodlandThe peculiar scene was discovered on Monday between Great Langdale and Little Langdale - a spot considered one of the most spectacular in the Lake DistrictThe table was set with plates, champagne flutes and water glasses Image: Ashley CooperByAlice Peacock:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments An abandoned afternoon tea set up featuring the remnants of a meal and a half-full glass of bubbles has been discovered in the middle of woodland in the Lake District. The peculiar scene was discovered on Monday between Great Langdale and Little Langdale, a spot considered one of the most spectacular in the area. The table was set with plates, champagne flutes and water glasses, as well as what appeared to be a two-level stand for cakes and a cheese platter. One plate had been polished off, while the other held remnants of a piece of cake, strawberries and cheese. From a small jar of jam and a bowl of what resembles whipped cream on the cake stand, it appeared likely that scones had featured as part of the meal.Photographer Ashley Cooper told the BBC he had first thought the table and chairs, which were set up a little less than m from the path, were part of an art installation.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter However, on closer inspection, it appeared the half-eaten food and glasses of fizz had been abandoned by a celebrating couple, he said.Mr Cooper thought it likely that the table had been left by someone from the Instagram generation.The Ambleside local, who works as a climate change photographer, had been walking in the woods when he spotted the odd set up. It looks like a romantic meal in the woods but then they couldnapost clean up after themselves,” he said. He pointed out that the couple had gone to a “lot of trouble” to carry the gear down from wherever they had come from - as it was about half a mile from the nearest road.  Staff at nearby hotels denied having anything to do with the set-up. Mr Cooper said it wasn’t unusual to see abandoned items around the area he said he had seen a number of tents, along with sleeping bags and cooking equipment, over the past  months. The region had proved popular with visitors as lockdown measures he eased, and there had been a type of visitor who had no respect for the place “whatsoever”. news world-news incredible-footage-shows-moment-huge-"Mediterranean Sea: Huge waterspout tornado passes cruise shipByAmy ReastChiara Fiorillo:,  Oct | commentsFootage filmed from a cruise ship shows the moment a huge tornado makes its way across the Mediterranean Sea. Sam Thompson, , was cruising from Rome to Palma de Mallorca when he spotted the incredible sight.He said the tornado happened after a perfectly clear day turned dark and stormy in minutes.The video, filmed on September , shows the tornado - known as a waterspout - making its way across the sea. It can be seen rising up from the middle of the sea in an impressive display, under a mile from the boat where Sam filmed the clip.Did you witness the tornado  Get in touch at webnews@mirror Travel agent Sam, from Bolton, Manchester, said: It was a beautul clear day and then all of a sudden we were in this dark cloud. I went outside and it was lashing it down with rain and there were these huge waves. As soon as the rain stopped, I saw this huge waterspout rise up from nowhere. It looked so cool. I knew I had to film it. Sam recalled the boat rocking in the force of the storm and the waterspout lasting for about three minutes, before vanishing as quickly as it came. After that, the weather ed to a clear blue sky once more, leaving no trace.Sam said: How often do you see something like that less than a mile away from you A waterspout is a column of rotating, cloud-filled wind descending to an ocean or lake, National Geographic explains.They are usually smaller and less intense than a tornado on land.  They are associated with severe thunderstorms and are often accompanied by high winds and seas, large hail, and frequent dangerous lightning, according to the National Ocean Service. Waterspouts are not as destructive as land tornados but could be dangerous for vessels and small craft in their way, All At Sea explains.They can cause havoc to mariners, as well as devastate coral reefs and marine organisms that are close to the wateraposs surface. title: jilted teen who plotted kidnap
story: Jilted teen who plotted to kidnap and murder crush stabbed her mum  times insteadAccording to the indictment, a -year-old had planned to kidnap his classmate at knepoint, before killing her and taking his own le - but instead another horric crime was committedJonathan R. had turned up at his crushs home wearing a balaclava, the court heardByAlice Peacock:,  Oct A teenager with an unrequited high school crush plotted to kidnap and kill his classmate but stabbed her mum  times instead after she opened the door, itaposs claimed. The accused, identied only as Jonathan R. has been charged with attempted murder in a trial that started on Monday in Cologne, Germany. According to the indictment, the -year-old had planned to kidnap his classmate, who did not share the same feelings he had for her, at knepoint. His plot next involved killing her, before taking his own le, itaposs alleged. However, it is claimed that when her mother opened the door, the balaclava-wearing teen lashed out in a fit of rage and stabbed her  times, critically injuring her.  But miraculously the victim survived and has appeared in court to testy against her alleged attacker. The defendant, who was classied as sane, told the courtroom he had “wanted to emigrate” with his crush, far away from the EU. “I was already making family plans,” he reportedly said. “But she didnapost respond to my messages.” He therefore “decided to die and take her with [him], the case against him states. Jonathan R.continued to explain he had wanted to “eliminate” anyone that got in his way. “I didnapost even realise the person who opened the door was her mother,” he reportedly told authoritises. He expressed apparent remorse for his act, stating: I am deeply ashamed. I regret it today. The -year-old victim, whose name was not reported, testied on the first day of the trial, explaining her daughter had never spoken about him. “When the doorbell rang in the evening, I thought it was my cousin and therefore opened the door slightly,” she said. But in front of me was a masked man who held up his right arm and began to stab me. She told the court how she still suffered from pain and sleepless nights following the horrying attack, which had taken place in April. The suspect was arrested shortly after, while his victim had to undergo emergency surgery to save her le. The court proceedings are expected to last until November . title: thought for the week september 24 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowI had the wonderful privilege the other week of holding a new grandson for the first time.Isn#t it amazing how a new-born infant can grab hold of your heart  I was filled with so much love and pride and I prayed that his le would be blessed.It so happened that the Gospel reading set for the Sunday after I met my grandson was, in part at least, about a little child.​Mark tells us Jesus was walking ahead of his disciples on the way to Capernaum. When they got there Jesus asked them: #What were you arguing about along the way #They couldn#t answer, for they had been arguing about which of them was the greatest. They were silent, because they#d been caught out.Then Jesus took a little child in his arms and said to them: #Whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me, and whoever welcomes me, welcomes not me but the one who sent me.#Greatness, Jesus was saying to them, is found in welcoming and receiving into our arms someone vulnerable, powerless and dependent, regardless of age.Greatness is found not in what we have accomplished but in what we have done and given to #the least of these#, the hungry, thirsty, naked, sick, and imprisoned: the symbolic children in each of our lives.Greatness never makes itself superior over another. It is not about me, my job, my reputation, my status. Our greatness is revealed in our service and care of others.Max is doing well, by the way, and I can hardly wait to see him again.God bless you and yours, from biggest to littlest, today and always.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Sir,Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca Helliwell wish to thank the community and patients of Mid Argyll Medical Practice for their kindness and good wishes marking their leaving the practice earlier this month.It has been a real privilege and honour to have been so closely and intimately involved with the lives of so many people and families over the last  and  years respectively.We will always be grateful for this and the opportunity to work with a excellent loyal and dedicated group of staff in the practice, hospital and in the wider NHS team.We will both continue to live locally and continue to work in the NHS in Argyll.Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca HelliwellSir,Looking into the future of marine planning, West Coast Regional Inshore Fisheries Grouphas formed an aquaculture sub-group to foster better communications and understanding between commercial fishing and aquaculture.Both are integral to coastal communities which are economically dependent on them.After the initial meeting it was agreed that there were synergies to be had working with other areas around Scotland, and the group was expanded to become simply the RIFG Aquaculture Working Group.The driving force comes from the proposed huge future expansion of aquaculture, the fact that fishers were not considered, historically, as mandatory consultees and also the promise of a review by Scottish Government of the aquaculture licencing process.It was felt that now was a good time for inshore fishers, through the RIFG, to consider, collate and communicate their views to any, and all, of the regulatory bodies involved in the said licencing process.The working group is particularly concerned with the aquaculture planning process # especially when it comes to the impact of proposed sites on traditional fishing grounds # poor site maintenance and monitoring which can lead to instances of vessel entanglement and also the environmental impact of the sites on both commercial and non-commercial species.The group believes that while the sector has made many advances over the past decade, increased transparency and oversight are needed to ensure the aquaculture sector can better co-exist with the fishing industry.The initial aim of the group would be to ensure that there is a proper analysis of localised fishing and follow up with clear and sensible communication between the two sectors to ensure that with expansion does not come conflict.It is a timeous idea, which will hopefully reassure fishermen that they will not simply be displaced by fish farming but will be respected for their own produce.The group will cement a policy to assist the fishing industry deal realistically with the fish farming industry and the Scottish Salmon Producers Organisation.Simon Macdonald, chair RIFG Aquaculture Work GroupSir,NFU Scotland is calling on the UK Government to address the nation’s growing labour crisis, which is undermining all parts of the food and drink supply chain, leading to signicant losses on some Scottish farms and resulting in a growing number of empty shop shelves.Last week#s #BackBritishFarmingDay on September  came as a UK Government announcement of a free trade #agreement in principle# between the UK and New Zealand is believed to be imminent.Having agreed in June to provide unfettered access in the future to Australia, the cumulative impact of another deal with a major exporting nation has huge signicance for Scottish farmers and crofters.With so much to celebrate about the quality and standards of our food and drink, #BackBritishFarmingDay was a fantastic opportunity to thank the nation for their incredible support throughout Brexit and Covid-.NFU Scotland, both independently and in conjunction with the Scottish food and drink industry, has written several times to UK Government calling for measures that address the shortfall in both seasonal and permanent staff.Should it fail to do so, I have absolutely no doubt that the situation will deteriorate further.It is galling to hear that the UK Government is on the verge of signing up to another free trade deal that will permit a growing level of imports while delivering very little to our food and drink sector in .The blunt fact is that neither deal has been afforded any kind of proper parliamentary scrutiny as the government’s promised Statutory Trade and Agriculture Commission has yet to be established.Safeguards against market disruption are also promised, but the cumulative impact of these deals will be profound for UK farming.If handled badly, these may make it impossible for some of our family farming businesses to continue to compete with high levels of low-cost imports produced to standards that would not be title: sru-coaching-boost-womens-rugby-borders
story: KELSO and Biggar are two of  Scottish rugby clubs selected to take part in a new SRU lsquoCoach Support Programmersquo in partnership with SP Energy Networks to support girlsrsquo rugby coaching groups across the country.The programme aims to strengthen coaching skills and support young female players towards performance improvements and will run initially between October and December .The Bordersrsquo sides will work with an appointed Coach Development Officer from Scottish Rugby, who will provide club coaches with bespoke support including -to- meetings, development plans, match and training observations and reviews.The  coaching groups selected for the programme are: Angus Girls, Kelpies Rugby, Garioch RFC, Orkney RFC, Edinburgh Harlequins, Kelso RFC, Biggar RFC, Whitecraigs RFC, Annan RFC and Greenock Wanderers.The programme kicked off on Monday  October with an online session for clubs to meet their Coach Development Officer and learn more about the programme, its details and objectives.Neil Graham, Head of Training  Education at Scottish Rugby said: ldquoWe are delighted to have SP Energy Networks supporting the delivery of the programme. Coaches are a crucial component in nurturing environments which allow players to develop and hone their skills.ldquoBy engaging in the programme our  selected coaching groups can expect to gain a deeper understanding of their coaching practice, identy areas of strength and development, and a greater breadth of knowledge to help them deal with day-to-day coaching situations.ldquoItrsquos our hope that the programme will create longer-term benefits for girls in the game, to keep them engaged with the sport and support their inidual overall development as they progress towards senior rugby.Frank Mitchell, CEO of SP Energy Networks said: ldquoSP Energy Networks is passionate about inspiring and supporting women and girls both on the rugby pitch, and in the workplace. Our partnership with the Scotland womenrsquos team is evidence of that commitment. Our aim has always been to support and drive forward grassroots rugby, placing ourselves closer to the communities we serve, whilst also striving to raise awareness of engineering as a career choice ndash especially for women and girls.ldquoTogether we have developed this new programme to break barriers and empower girlsrsquo rugby across Scotland. It is a deepening of our support of womenrsquos rugby in Scotland, to ensure that potential international stars of the future are working with best-in-class coaches.ldquoThe work these coaches have already done, and will continue to do, is instrumental in inspiring the next generation and we are proud to support them through this and beyond.

story: AFTER A long period of no competitive rugby, Southern Knights are thrilled to have reached the  final of the FOSROC Super Rugby League and are particularly grateful to main sponsor global IT and business consulting services company CGI for their support over the past two years.Rob Chrystie, Head coach at the Southern Knights, said: ldquoThe Southern Knights management and players have really enjoyed theirto rugby since the end of July.CGI, our headline sponsor have shown unwavering support to the Southern Knights throughout extremely challenging times. story: A BORDERS MP has commented on the proposed constituency boundary changes which could come into force as part of the  Review.The Boundary Commission of Scotland published its proposals yesterdaywhich outlined new boundary lines for UK constituencies in Scotland.As part of the review there has been a "minor change" to Clovenfords and Caddonfoot in the Berwickshire, Roxburgh, and Selkirk constituency ndash as part of the  review they will be brought into the Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale constituency.:Two cars involved in lsquocollisionrsquo on road near Borders town, according to policeBerwickshire, Roxburgh, and Selkirk MP John Lamont, who represents the Conservatives, said: "I have always been of the view that during any boundary review the Borders communities within the existing constituency of Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk should remain in one constituency."Although there are minor changes around Clovenfords, I am pleased to see that principle recognised in the Commissions initial proposals."Under this review, Berwickshire, Roxburgh, and Selkirk will have an electorate of ,, and Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale will have an electorate of ,.:Committee "chuffed" with turnout as Borders community shop officially opensThere will now be an eight-week-long consultation process for constituents to have their say on the proposed boundary changes across Scotlands  constituencies.Mr Lamont added: ldquoAs we now enter an eight week consultation period, I would encourage local residents to take part in the consultation as it is vital that views from Borderers are heard."I look forward to the outcome of this process.To view the existing and proposed boundaries, and take part in the consultation, visit: www.bcomm-scotland.independent.gov.uk

title: always-turn-sir-david-amess-community-charity-work-remembered
story: Sir David Amess has been remembered for his charity work, with constituents describing him as a ldquocommunity man who would ldquoalways turn up.Helen Symmons is the town clerk for Leigh-On-Sea, and said Sir Davidrsquos death was a ldquomassive shock for the whole town.ldquoIrsquove lived here for  years, and hersquos always been my MP as long as Irsquove lived here, the -year-old told the PA news agency.ldquoDavid was a big community man and everybody here recognised that.ldquoEveryonersquos in a state of shock and disbelief.vw, px"Sir David with former Leigh-on-Sea council chairman Jill Healey during Christmas celebrations Mrs Symmons recalled Sir Davidrsquos annual attendance at the townrsquos Christmas parade, which attracts between five and ten thousand people each year.ldquoWe always invited David, he always came along and we always found him a float to sit in and wave from, she said.ldquoI think the worst thing that I made him do was probably sithellip with a mascot dressed as a bear.Mrs Symmons said Sir David ldquonever complained, adding: ldquoEvenhis diary was completely chock-a-blockhellip he always turned up.ldquoI remember when we had the royal wedding in , there were so many street parties around here, and he literally attended every one ndash every single street party.ldquoIt was a massive undertaking for him to do and, and just show the commitment that he had as a community man.Mrs Symmons said Sir David also organised an annual party for all the centenarians in the area, and was ldquomassively involved with the Royal British Legion.He was also patron and president of the Music Man Project Charity, an international music education service for people with disabilities.In , he helped the charity ndash which he was involved with for more than  years ndash organise an event in which  children with learning disabilities played music at the Royal Albert Hall.For those who didnrsquot know Sir David Amess, this will give you a measure of the man. Irsquod played a small part in helping him get  children with learning disabilities to play the #@RoyalAlbertHall#. This is the video I filmed on the night of his thank you speech. pic aFSCiPdkmdash Penny MordauntOctober , The charityrsquos founder, David Stanley, said he was ldquodevastated when he heard the news, adding he and Sir David had been friends for several years after meeting in his Southend constituency.ldquoThe news came as the most devastating shock. He gave me opportunities to do music, dinners and receptions at the House of Commons, Mr Stanley told PA.ldquoWe were planning the next stage, which was we were hoping to perform on Broadway and do other shows at the Albert Hall. He was central to making those dreams come true.ldquoAs you can imagine people with learning disabilities, that they canrsquot really change their own destiny, they need people to help them. Sir David was able to do things that I couldnrsquot do as a charity founder. He could and he was just amazing in what he did.All our hearts are full of shock and sadness at the death of Sir David Amess MP.He was one of the kindest, nicest, most gentle people in politics. pic SIxSZPwmdash Boris JohnsonOctober , Kimberley OrsquoConnor, a community activist from Leigh-On-Sea, said she saw Sir David at the charity St Vincentrsquos Centre Southend, and that he was regularly seen at community events.Ms OrsquoConnor, , said: ldquoHe was a well-known foot soldier. Always out and about in the area.ldquoHe was only at St Vincentrsquos Centre Southend when I was there recently, supporting the work they do for the homeless and vulnerable.ldquoHe was . title: scottish-parliament-recess-happens-mean-scotland
story: The Scottish Parliament is on recess from October  - , meaning chamber meetings and ministerial statments will not take place this week.Parliament recesses are breaks from normal order and usually take place several times a year in line with school and bank holidays.What do these recesses mean for politicsin Scotland  Heres everything you need to know...What areParliament recesses Parliament recesses arebreaks in the normal schedule when there are no meetings in the Chamber and no committee meetings.The Ocotberrecess is often seen as an "October holiday" for MSPs, althoughit is unlikely they will take the whole recess to recuperate.Do MSPs continue working during Parliament recess The recess allows MSPs to spend an extended period of time in their own constituencyand therefore with their constituents.MSPs are likely to take advantage of this time to maintain or increase rapport with their constituents by attending local events and generally keeping a fairly high profile.Recesses give MSPs time to make the visits that they might in normal times be too busy to carry out.Do First Ministers Questions continue during recess No, First Ministers Questions will not continue during recess.However, Parliament can be recalled over the course ofrecessrequired.Can Parliament berecalled at any time Parliament can be recalled from recess on request of the Government.For example, Parliament was recalled during recess in April following the death of Prince Philipto allow politicians in Scotlandto pay tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.Can I still contact my MSP during Parliamentary recess Yes, you can still get in contact with your MSP during recesses and they may table questions to ask when Parliament s.When does the UK Parliament take nextrecess The UK Parliament will takerecess from November -.

title: christmas-shortages-2021-homemade-christmas-gift-ideas
story: With warnings of Christmas shortages due to supply chain issues and delivery delays, you might be thinking about giving homemade gts this year.Covid- and Brexitare among contributing factors, while an escalating dispute over fishing rights has led French fishing representatives to threaten a blockade at Calais to stop exports to the UK.Current issues have been put down to a "transition period" by Boris Johnsons administration, which they say will not cause "much risk" at Christmas.However, asindustry experts deemChristmas shortages "a certainty", making your own presents could help you to avoid potential delays or disappointment.Not only that, but family and friends are sure to appreciate the time andeffort that goes into creating ahand crafted gt.Here are some ideas for homemade presents this Christmas.... Homemade jam and chutneyThe festive period is a time for eating, so what better than cooking up a big batch of homemade jam or chutney for your loved ones.Start saving your jars now and by Christmas you will have plenty to fill.Hundreds of recipescan be found online andyou are cooking in large quantities, it wont necessarily be that expensive!Another positive is the long shelf le of such products, meaning people can enjoy them well into .. Christmas decorationsChristmas tree decorationsare an underrated gt - with people using the same items year after year, and even generation after generation, this could be your opportunity to leave your stamp on celebrations for decades to come.There are plenty of ideas online, but why not buy some cheap, clear plastic or glass bobbles which you can decorate with permanent markers, tippex pens or paint, before tying with ribbon.Baked salt dough can work just as well, while simple origami folding techniques can be used to transform a piece of paper into something special.. Photo albumsA photo album filled with memories could be the best present someone ever receives.It may be slightly time consuming, but a collection of photos reminding your loved ones of a special time in their le is a timeless classic which will never get old.Photo albums can be cheaply purchasedonline or in store - charity shops are a good place to start - and companieslike Free Printsmean you can order photographs for free from your phone.. Knitted socksIf you are a keen knitter, homemade socks are guaranteed to please as well as keep people warm through the cold winter months.. Sloe ginSloe gin is synonymous with aChristmas tipple, and as it turns out its pretty easy to make yourself, with some recipes only requiring three ingredients.Again, start saving bottles and by December you will be ready to decant.. Christmas bakingYou cant go wrong with some Christmas baking, whether it be mince pies, yule logs or mini Christmas puddings.Pop it in a box and tie with ribbon and you have yourself the perfect gt which will go down a treat while people wait for Christmas dinner.. VouchersIf you dont want to give physical gts, you could make a voucher for an experience to take your loved one out for coffee or dinner once the festive season is over.Its something to look forward to once Christmas is over, and gives you a chance to catch up on each others lives after the busy end-of-year period.

title: safari-park-launches-halloween-activities-pumpkin-patch-ahead-school-holidays

title: stirling-city-culture-scottish-city-makes-longlist---means
story: Stirling has been longlisted for the City of Culture , along with sevenother cities around the UK.It was one of three Scottish areas to apply, but the only one to make this years longlist in culture.The idea was catalysed by Liverpools successas the European Capital of Culture in , with the first UK city of culture awarded to Derry Londonderry in .Kingston upon Hull won in  while Coventry from capital investment to support ious cultural projects.The awardhas the potential to regenerate cities, with Hull attractingmore than . million visits to over , events during its tenure.Culture cultural activities to drive tourism.Which other Scottish cities applied for the City of Culture  This year saw the biggest list of applicants yet, with  in total including threeScottish cities.The title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. title: musician-brings-back-fond-memories-musselburgh-nursing-home
story: Dr Claire Garabedian and her nine-year-old terrier Rusty visited Harbour House, near Fisherrow Harbour, where she met residents, relatives and staff.She played well-known songs such as My Bonnie, You Are My Sunshine and Over The Rainbow, free improvisations and classical music.She said: ldquoBetween tunes, I asked and welcomed questions, and I explained a bit about what music can do towards encouraging connection and engagement ndash a sonic haven ndash and what I do as a therapeutic musician.Rusty, who Claire rehomed last November, was also a big hit with the audience. She said: ldquoHe is partially blind with cataracts and a social opportunist. He simply loves being around people and is very gentle and intuitive.Claire, who lives near Harbour House, would like to extend her performances in nursing and care homes to people living in their own homes.She said: ldquoWhile playing for a small group is fun and effective, the smaller the group, all the way down to one-to-one, the more effectively the music can be towards facilitating connection.Claire is a professional cellist, baroque cellist and therapeutic musician whose doctoral and post-doctoral research focuses on effectively using the arts, especially music, as a means of engagement and a connection with people who are living with dementia, including family and friends.She said: ldquoIrsquove found that music can generate connections and equality among all who are present ndash listening or playing music together regardless of any physical cognitive conditions.Claire has enjoyed sharing her knowledge and experiences on some big stages, such as the Hay Festival and BBC Radio  .A Harbour House spokesperson said: ldquoThe residents said they found Clairersquos performance both calming and relaxing. Some commented on how the songs played brought back some fond memories. There was lots of reminiscing following Clairersquos visit.More information about Claire and her work can be found at drclairegarabedian

title: call-green-fingered-volunteers-wallyford
story: The community initiative lsquoWallyford in Bloomrsquo has been launched by The Destiny Project SCIO, a mental health charity.Andrew Stevenson, the charityrsquos project manager, said: ldquoThe main aim of the initiative is to bring people together that live and work in Wallyford.ldquoWe want to create a bloom of colour within the village.He explained that Wallyford in Bloom was linked with the projectrsquos adoption of Wallyford Railway Station as part of ScotRailrsquos lsquoAdopt a Stationrsquo scheme.He said: ldquoWe are appealing to the people of Wallyford of all ages to come join us to contribute in the delivery of Wallyford in Bloom.Enthusiastic fundraisers were also welcome to support the charity and lsquoIn Bloomrsquo initiative.Mr Stevenson said: ldquoWallyford is a place I spent a brief part of my childhood and is a special place to me.He added: ldquoWe aim to create a little colour with planters throughout the village and would also like to create an lsquoAdopt Your Streetrsquo project to promote litter picking.ldquoThe main aim is to bring people together from all walks of le and to promote the importance of the environment. We currently have a handful of volunteers, with many more interested, but there is always room for more.It is hoped to involve local children in the railway station project by asking them to create their own rock drawings of their favourite things about where they live.ldquoThis will surround a large lsquoWALLYFORDrsquo on the mound at the  in the shape of a carriage. There will also be the shape of a train with flowers within it, with the objective to promote the STEAM fields of science, technology, engineering, art and maths, Mr Stevenson added.Anyone interested in getting involved with Wallyford in Bloom can email Mr Stevenson at andrewthedestinyproject@gmail or check out the Wallyford in Bloom and Destiny Project Facebook pages.The Destiny Project provides support and advocacy to communities.It works with other agencies to provide a wide range of services, particularly for the most vulnerable in the community.The charity promotes the health and wellbeing of children and young people, building skills that will create a positive impact on their lives by working on matters such as education and training, and the environment.The project recognises the ldquoimportant role that volunteers play in communities and aims to actively encourage and support its volunteers.

title: historic-farm-building-turned-office-near-longniddry

title: honorary-consulate-czech-republic-officially-opens-musselburgh
story: The Czech Republicrsquos last Honorary Consul, Dr Paul Millar, retired recently after -plus years of service to the Czech community in Scotland, and his honorary consulate in Edinburgh closed its doors. title: east-end-north-berwick-high-street-close-two-weeks
story: The works, which will be for a -month trial scheme, are due to start on Monday, October  and last for no more than two weeks - though will, say the local authority, ldquorequire a temporary road closure but access for pedestrians will be maintained.It will include:bull Widening of existing pavements through the use of temporary materialsbull New double yellow lines and appropriate traffic signagebull Consolidation of loading bay facilitiesbull Keeping some of the plantersbull Fixing fallen kerbs and broken surfacing of footwaysbull Maintenance of some street lightingCouncillor Norman Hampshire, the local autjorityrsquos environment spokesman, said: ldquoIn , a series of proposals to improve access to the town centre were discussed as part of the North Berwick charrette organised through the local Area Partnership.ldquoMore than  main projects were identied by the local community and a priority was to consider improvements for the east end of the High Street which would create more space for people to walk safely.ldquoAn agreed scheme was ready for construction in early  but was delayed as a result of the Covid pandemic halting all non-essential construction works.ldquoHowever, the pandemic did provide opportunities for temporary changes of public access. As part of the national Spaces for People initiative to create room for social distancing in town centres, a number of planters and reduction of public parking have been in place in North Berwick over the past  months.ldquoInformal consultation has suggested that the increased space and reduced parking has been beneficial to the businesses and wider community.The existing one-way system through Market Place will remain while the trial is ongoing.Following the trial period the design may require to be adjusted before funding is sought to implement a final scheme using appropriate permanent materials.

title: brave-tranent-dad-chased-bike-thief-street-bare-feet
story: Last Wednesday at about .pm, Ewan Reynoldsrsquo sonrsquos mountain bike was taken from their garden at Farsquoside Avenue in Tranent.Ewan explained that the bike, a size small Trek Roscoe  in grey red with yellow writing on the tyres, was taken from the back door of their home.His partner Kirsty heard the culprit outside on the garden stones.When she opened the back door, she witnessed the thief holding the bike in the air and making his way down the driveway.Immediately, Kirsty called for Ewanrsquos help and he raced down the garden in his bare feet to chase the thief up the street.Unfortunately, the culprit made his escape in the direction of the bus terminal at the zebra crossing near Windygoul Co-op.Ewan added: ldquoMy son was absolutely gutted due to the theft as he goes out on his bike every day after school and is always out on his bike at the weekends, as thatrsquos what he and his pals do.The bike has since been recovered from a garden in Tranent.Ewan said he was notied of information about the whereabouts of the bike and retrieved it on Monday evening.

title: residents-plant-wildflower-patch-east-linton
story: The workshop was part of CAELrsquos Wildle Network project, launched this spring.CAEL is working towards a lower-carbon, resilient community, with local nature flourishing, and is dedicated to educating residents about East Lothian landscapes.Jo Gibb,a steering group member, said: ldquoAs well as a climate crisis, we are in the middle of a global bioersity crisis and as a response to this, the Wildle Network aims to create corridors of wildle-friendly gardens, where spaces in gardens are dedicated to creating habitats for wildle through wild areas, water features, wildflower patches, bug hotels and many other options.ldquoThe idea was inspired by the Felixstowe Community Nature Reserve Little Green Space and a number of other communities in the UK have since followed similar models.ldquoAs part of the Wildle Network, open garden days have been organised for people to visit and learn from rowan and elder trees provided for those interesteda demonstration border at East Linton park establishedand workshops on dferent themes organised.At the Wildle Networkrsquos Wildflower Workshop, local residents came together to learn about how to establish and manage a wildflower area dedicated to providing bioerse habitats for wildle.Sally Gouldstone, from skincare company Seilich, ran the workshop, which saw participants sowing a wildflower area in East Linton War Memorial Park.Attendees were also provided with native seeds to take home and sow in their own gardens, with the idea that multiple wildflower patches would be established in the East Linton area.Recently, seeds and a scythe to help manage wildflower areas were purchased through funding provided by NatureScot.The scythe will be made available for the local community to use from the East Linton Tool Library.

title: part-musselburgh-set-removed-east-lothian-constituency-general-elections
story: Changes are being considered to the countys Westminster constituency ndash which until now has exactly matched the county boundaries ndash under proposals being made up by The Boundary Commission for Scotland.One of the proposals is to see Musselburgh residents who live to the west of the River Esk included in the Edinburgh East constituency.That would include areas of the Capital such as Portobello and Duddingston.This map shows the proposed Edinburgh East constituency, included the western part of MusselburghThe rest of the East Lothian constituency would then be renamed East Lothian Coast and would continue to include the part of Musselburgh to the east of the river.This map shows the proposed East Lothian Coast constituency, containing the rest of East LothianThe proposals were revealed today , marking the start of an eight-week consultation.For Scotland as a whole, the number of MPs would be cut from  to .Meanwhile, there would  additional MPs in England, eight fewer in Wales and no change in Northern Ireland.Lord Matthews, Deputy Chair of the Boundary Commission for Scotland, said: ldquoI believe this is a promising start to delivering the requirements of the new rules that mean the number of constituencies in Scotland will reduce from  to , and that each mainland constituency must have broadly the same number of electors.ldquoWe have set out proposals today which do that and are, we believe, a good implementation of the rules set by Parliament.ldquoToday is the beginning of a process and we now want to hear the views of the public.ldquoWe will reflect on responses to the consultation and make changes where appropriate and where the legislation allows us to do so.ldquoWe strongly encourage voters to make their views heard.At the last General Election in East Lothian, Kenny MacAskill won the seat for the SNP by a majority of , over incumbent Labour MP Martin Whitfield ndash Mr MacAskill has since left the SNP and joined the ALBA Party.The proposed changes would have no effect to the existing Scottish Parliament constituencies, which see Musselburgh, Wallyford and Whitecraig included as part of the Midlothian North and Musselburgh constituency, and the rest of the county in the East Lothian constituency.

title: public-say-future-20mph-speed-limits-east-lothian
story: Speed limits throughout towns and villages ndash and on the approach to settlements ndash were reduced last year in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.The speed limit on the approach to many distancing and in East Lothian we were able to introduce a number of measures including mph limits leading into our towns and villages.ldquoThese were implemented under temporary Traffic Orders and we title: home-bargains-open-haddington-retail-park-weekend-55-new-jobs
story: The national chain is the latest retailer to open in Haddington Retail Park, with the new shop officially opening its doors for the first time on Saturday at am.Already, Costa Coffee, The Food Warehouse and Aldi are welcoming customers on the townrsquos western edge.Ahead of the opening, Home Bargains also confirmed it would be making a pound, donation to Haddington-based good cause the Lammermuir Larder.Magdalena Cosgrove, the new Home Bargains store manager at Haddington Retail Park, was looking forward to welcoming customers this weekend.She said: ldquoIrsquove worked in the retail sector for many years, but therersquos nothing quite like the buzz of opening a new store.ldquoFour years ago, I helped launch our Craigmillar Shopping Centre site, so I know how much hard work and dedication goes into something like this.ldquoI canrsquot wait to open the store this weekend alongside such a fantastic team ndash itrsquos something that Irsquom exceptionally proud of.The more than ,-square-foot store will offer shoppers a range of products, including homewares, health and beauty essentials, sweets, snacks and drinks, as well as fresh and frozen food.Pat Lemmon, founder of the Lammermuir Larder, welcomed the four-figure donation.The volunteer-led food initiative provides people in need with a weekrsquos shopping, fresh fruit and vegetables, and a meat voucher.Mrs Lemmon, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said: ldquoWe are over the moon to be picked as the local group to benefit from this wonderful donation from Home Bargains.ldquoThis money will go a long way in helping many people in the Haddington and Lammermuir area who are currently struggling financially and worried about putting food on the table.A petrol station is also planned for the retail park, with one remaining unit yet to be filled.

title: gas-works-see-road-closures-prestonpans-13-weeks
story: SGN announced that it would begin work to upgrade its gas network in the Prestonpans area on Monday.The work involves replacing ,m of old metal gas mains and service pipes with new plastic pipe, ensuring a continued safe and reliable gas supply to the local community.SGN has planned its work in close consultation with local authorities to reduce disruption as much as possible.The project will be carried out by SGN contractor George Ritchie  Son.During the works, parking restrictions will be in operation allowing safe access to the pipe ndash some road closures will also be required.Temporary traffic signals will be in operation at certain times, which may cause delays during peak periods.Emergency vehicle access will be maintained throughout the work.The gas work will be suspended during the Christmas holidays, with operatives ing early in the new year.Road closures include Prestongrange Terracersquos junction with Prestongrange Road, and Polwarth Terracersquos junction with Gardiner Terrace.To minimise disruption, SGN work will be carried out on a phased basis and not all streets will be affected at the same time.Access to driveways and garages will be maintained unless previously agreed with the occupier.An SGN spokesperson said: ldquoWersquoll be working as quickly as possible to complete our work and will be making every effort to minimise inconvenience to the local community.Suspension of parking is as follows:Prestonpans Community Council is calling for greater clarity on road works in and around the town, ideally in the form of an interactive map showing all the restrictions over time.A spokesperson for the community council said: ldquoInidual roadworks are obviously necessary for the maintenance of our public utilities.ldquoHowever, there is a balance to be struck between maintenance and what can quickly become a public nuisance.ldquoIf roadworks are all planned to minimise distribution, there is currently no way of telling. For example, Blindwells seems to open and close our key access road to the A on a whim.ldquoWith all the building works going on, there needs to be much tighter management, notication and planning.ldquoDevelopers should also be held to schedule and asked to contribute to the local community for unnecessary job overruns and traffic delays.ldquoOne key concern, for example, is the timing of sequencing on temporary lights.ldquoSequence settings can have a huge impact on road users.ldquoThese lights should be independently assessedleft in place longer than a day.ldquoThis is the information technology age letrsquos start using it to manage and monitor our service providers.SGN said it would be writing to residents and other local stakeholders to make them aware of the project.Residents with enquiries about the project can call SGN on   .

title: day-activities-dunbar-start-pilgrims-walk-cop26-climate-conference
story: Walkers will follow the John Muir Way from Dunbar to Glasgow for the COP climate conference.Ahead of setting off from John Muirrsquos Birthplace, on Dunbarrsquos High Street, a number of family friendly events are taking place in the townrsquos Lauderdale Park.North Light Arts, Sustaining Dunbar and Friends of John Muirrsquos Birthplace are working to put together the special day on Sunday.It is hoped the day will bring together free activities that highlight environmental messages surrounding the ongoing climate emergency, the importance of the human relationship to the earthrsquos soils and nature, a celebration of the pilgrims and the experience of contemplative walking with a special purpose.The events get under way at pm and feature Rowanbank Environmental Arts, a printing workshop by Rebellious Threads, bike-powered flour milling with Shed Therapy, storytelling with the Courierrsquos Tim Porteus and pizza-making with Muddy Buddies.St Annersquos Church will display Stitches for Survival craftivism banners, and offer space for creative prayer, reflection and guided meditations.A led sensory slow walk will begin from John Muirrsquos Birthplace at pm to the harbour, where music and readings will take place within the Battery from .pm.The Battery performance programme includes poetry by Rita Bradd, readings by the Battery Theatre, a special performance by Dunbar Voices of Enough Is Enough, a song written by Oi Musica and Karine Polwart for COP, and a unique Keeper of the Soils ceremony.The day will be rounded off at Belhaven Church Hall with a pilgrimsrsquo supper and a thought-provoking talk by Alastair McIntosh.The pilgrims will set off the following day and make their way to Glasgow in time for the conference, which begins at the end of the month.

title: scotland-cricketers-play-icc-mens-t20-world-cup-kit-designed-haddington-schoolgirl
story: The ICC Menrsquos T World Cup gets under way in the United Arab Emirates and Oman this weekend.Scotland, who start their tournament against Bangladesh this Sunday, will be wearing a design created by Haddingtonrsquos Rebecca Downie.The youngsterrsquos pattern was chosen from more than  entries from schoolchildren across Scotland. title: scottish-parliament-recess-happens-mean-scotland
story: Parliament recesses are breaks from normal order and usually take place several times a year in line with school and bank holidays.What do these recesses mean for politics in Scotland  Heres everything you need to know...Parliament recesses arebreaks in the normal schedule when there are no meetings in the Chamber and no committee meetings.The Ocotberrecess is often seen as an "October holiday" for MSPs, althoughit is unlikely they will take the whole recess to recuperate.The recess allows MSPs to spend an extended period of time in their own constituencyand therefore with their constituents.MSPs are likely to take advantage of this time to maintain or increase rapport with their constituents by attending local events and generally keeping a fairly high profile.Recesses give MSPs time to make the visits that they might in normal times be too busy to carry out.No, First Ministers Questions will not continue during recess.However, Parliament can be recalled over the course ofrecessrequired.Parliament can be recalled from recess on request of the Government.For example, Parliament was recalled during recess in April following the death of Prince Philipto allow politicians in Scotland to pay tribute to the Duke of Edinburgh.Yes, you can still get in contact with your MSP during recesses and they may table questions to ask when Parliament s.The UK Parliament will takerecess from November -.

title: christmas-shortages-2021-homemade-christmas-gift-ideas
story: Covid- and Brexit are among contributing factors, while an escalating dispute over fishing rights has led French fishing representatives to threaten a blockade at Calais to stop exports to the UK.Current issues have been put down to a "transition period" by Boris Johnsons administration, which they say will not cause "much risk" at Christmas.However, asindustry experts deemChristmas shortages "a certainty", making your own presents could help you to avoid potential delays or disappointment.Not only that, but family and friends are sure to appreciate the time andeffort that goes into creating ahand crafted gt.Here are some ideas for homemade presents this Christmas...The festive period is a time for eating, so what better than cooking up a big batch of homemade jam or chutney for your loved ones.Start saving your jars now and by Christmas you will have plenty to fill.Hundreds of recipes can be found online andyou are cooking in large quantities, it wont necessarily be that expensive!Another positive is the long shelf le of such products, meaning people can enjoy them well into .Christmas tree decorationsare an underrated gt - title: best-graphic-novels-havent-heard
story: ldquoIn Good Cop, Detective Inspector Brian Fisher seeks to put the past behind him and free himself from his lsquoBad Coprsquo persona once and for all, Alexander explains. ldquoBut itrsquos not easy to turn your back on a dark history of depravity and violence. Fisher is about to discover his inner demons wonrsquot let go without a fight.In the past Alexander has written for AD, Marvel and DC and today for Graphic Content he reveals some of his influences. This is his choice of the graphic novels you might not have heard of but should have.A History of ViolenceJohn Wagner and Vince LockeViggo Mortensen in David Cronenbergs adaptation of History of ViolenceItrsquos fair to say that John Wagner is best known as co-creator and chief propagator of Judge Dredd. A History of Violence [later turned into a film by David Cronenberg] sees the writer depart from the sprawl of post-apocalyptic Mega-Cities to modern-day small-town America. The initial premise is a simple one, but brilliant in its execution. A reluctant hero gets his picture in the paper and is recognised by some very bad people from his past. Wagnerrsquos writing never misses a beat, building the tension up to a massively exciting and satisfying conclusion. Itrsquos accompanied by Vince Lockersquos art, which is never flashy, keeps you in the moment, and presents every scene to maximum effect. A masterpiece in storytelling.Bad CompanyPeter Milligan and Brett Ewins and othersTake a futuristic Dirty Dozen and place them in a never-ending war against a brutal alien invader. Another simple concept, but it comes alive in the hands of writer Peter Milligan. Chock-a-block with broken, warped and wonderfully evocative characters inside and out, and aided and abetted by deliriously trippy, twisted visuals by original artist, the late Brett Ewins. Unrelenting and gut-clenching. The only thing in Bad Company with a heart is darkness itself.The O menby Martin EdenThe most striking aspect of this book is its ordinariness. But thatrsquos no criticism, anything but. Normally we have a superhero team portrayed as dysal characters, who see their powers as much a curse as a blessing, with a pressing need to get together to take on a greater threat.In the O men, we have superheroes whose powers, in the face of the everyday issues, are incidental. The type of issues we all face in terms of relationships, making ends meet, looking forward to the weekend.Think of your favourite soap-cum-kitchen sink drama with a sprinkling of superhero powers. It shouldnrsquot work, but it does. Created from the febrile mind of Martin Eden it displays the full range of indie punk sensibilities.theomenix.org.ukThe Ballad of Halo JonesBy Alan Moore and Ian GibsonBest known for comic behemoths Watchmen and V for Vendetta, Alan Moore is also capable of more nuanced work. The Ballad of Halo Jones is deliberately understated and all the better for it. Set in the future, Halo Jones is an ordinary person who finds herself in extraordinary circumstances. We first find her on a shopping trip where timing is everything. Then, in desperate need of a job, she enlists as a soldier in a future war. Finally, she is lover to an all-powerful warlord.Moore is at the top of his game as he fills in the gaps. Nothing is forced. Itrsquos all about character development, and itrsquos through this that we care as well. I first read Halo Jones in the late s. Beautully and meticulously drawn by Ian Gibson, who brings to le images and scenes that have stayed with me all my adult le.Chief OrsquoBrien at WorkBy Jon AdamsTake a secondary character from Star Trek the Next Generation. A Transporter Chief no less. Hersquos always there, ready to transport the major characters onto the surface of some alien planet or other, but never really appreciated by his peers . From such unpromising beginnings is born a cult comedy classic. Jon Adams describes it thus: ldquoFor fans of crappy jobs, space travel, and ennui. And I guess,itrsquos on this list, I must be a fan as well!The book consists of single-page comic strips with the main character always upbeat and happy to help despite the constant putdowns. OrsquoBrien remains statuesque in many of his scenes. Unmoving, someone you wouldnrsquot notice twice. The result is, by turn, unexpectantly charming, sad, and very, very funny. Chief OrsquoBrien at Work has to be read to be believed.chiefobrienatworkGood Cop by Jim Alexander is out on paperback and on Kindle and available from Amazon, Barnes and Noble and Kobo.

title: covid-scotland-scotlands-declining-rates-attributed-masks-passports
story: Tim Spector, a professor of genetic epidemiology at Kings College London,said Scotlands Covid rates had come down faster than other parts of the UK and said the country also hadsome of the highest rates of vaccinations.The Scottish Government has delayed the introduction of passports until October  which will meansnightclubs and large events are only able to allow entry to people who can show they have had two doses of a Covid vaccine.Prof Spector,who fronts the ZOE Covid symptom tracker app,said he was against the measure in the Summer "because I didnt think we would need them".Research carried out by the team on social media found an overwhelming majority in the UK were against the introduction of vaccine passports.He said: ldquoScotlandrsquos rates have come down the fastest and it also has some of the highest rates of vaccination in the UK."At least % in most regions andWales and Scotland are really the only two areas which have maintained some form of social distancing and mask wearing as well as some degree of vaccine certication.: Scotland records more than  new Covid cases and  deaths in past  hoursldquoItrsquos early days but we did a couple of polls and we had over , people voting on Twitter and the results were a convincing no ndash % said no and % said yes. On Facebook, initially it was completely reversed until I tweeted about it and in the last  hours that has been reversed as well.ldquoI think you canrsquot generalise from social media polls ndash they donrsquot usually represent the wider population but it shows there is a lot of disagreement out there and a fear about introducing them."We will have to see what happens in Scotland and Wales but I think itrsquos worth looking at the international scene to see how other countries have managed to get their cases and hospitalisations down, using these routes.Countries which have introduced some form of certication include Belgium, Ireland, France and Italy.ldquoWhat we do see those countries have a much higher rate of vaccination and we are slipping back. Denmark interesting launched a vaccine passport and now that is has % of people vaccinated it has relaxed those rules.ldquoOur population is still only % vaccinated and single shots are offering very little protection against the Delta iant.: Two doses of one vaccineprovides % protection after Covid infection, study shows"Israel is a good example of country which introduced a vaccine passport and their rates of infection are now lower than ours.Prof Spector said the fact that the Westminster government was reluctantto maintainother basic measures such as mask wearing and social distancing meant "wemay have to think of other options and you do run out of these ones".He said: "The mindset is there is one magic bullet that is going to cure us ndash none of these on their own are going to do that. You do need all of these and public awareness of symptoms and home testing before you go into the office or school.ldquoI think itrsquos still important we continue to wash our hands and wear masks. We do need to find a way to increase vaccination rates as we go into winter."ldquoAs we creep towards the two year mark of this pandemic, itrsquos important to note that we still have Covid rates that are too high, we have long Covid rates that are too high and although hospitalisations are relatively few, we are not out of the woods yet."In a way this idea of herd immunity and the power of being infected, meaning you donrsquot get it again has pervaded a lot of our thinking around Covid and I think a lot of our mistakes."He said the total number of UK cases had increased slightly from last week at ,, and included, who have been fully vaccinated.ldquoThe deaths averaged at around  last week, which is around  a day and slightly down from last week. Long Covid has gone up a bit at about  people estimated to getting it every day and hospitalisations have gone up slightly to  a day.:Scotlands vaccine passports: When will I need to show itldquo people are actually very sick and on ventilators. These are the highest rates wersquove seen since the winter in January."Most of these cases are still in the under s and we have been seeing for the past few weeks but some good newsyou look at the age graphs we have seen a decline from that peak and although it would be nice to think thatrsquos vaccination but itshappened before thatrsquos really had time to effect and the vaccination programme has been very slow in kids."He said it was worrying that rates are increasing in the  to  age bracket.ldquoThese are the parents now getting infected. At the moment the other groups are staying pretty steady and havenrsquot yet been affected.ldquoWe are seeing a levelling off of those increases in most areas and the notably exception is the decline that has carried on in Scotland consistently. Wales looks asitrsquos going down nicely too butwe have yet to see those changes in the rest of England.
